   (A)   Definitions:
      PLAT SURVEY: A staked lot/plat showing all improvements and proposed
improvements within property lines and placing stakes at lot corners in
accordance with Illinois minimum standards. Such survey shall include
centerline stationing, curb offsets, proposed buildings and setbacks, lot area
and lot dimensions. Surveys prepared for submission to the city of Aledo shall
be stamped/sealed by a state of Illinois licensed land surveyor or professional
engineer.
      TOPOGRAPHICAL SURVEYS (May Be Required For New Subdivisions, Commercial
And Industrial Buildings): A survey showing contours and elevations of a tract
of land in relation to an established landmark. Topographical surveys prepared
for submission to the city of Aledo shall be stamped/sealed by a state of
Illinois licensed professional engineer. (Ord. 06-19-06-1, 8-21-2006)
4-1-4: FENCES:
The following regulations shall govern the construction, alteration,
modification and maintenance of fences, as defined, within the city of Aledo.
Every fence constructed, erected, altered, replaced or enlarged after the
effective date hereof shall comply with the provisions of this section.
Existing fences, constructed or having a permit issued prior to the adoption of
this section, shall be allowed to continue as lawful, nonconforming fences so
long as they are maintained.
   (A)   Permit: A permit shall be required for all fences, as defined. A
permit is not required for nonpermanent landscaping, construction or snow
fencing (fencing that is easy to remove, not embedded in ground).
   (B)   Definitions:
      FENCE: A tangible barrier constructed or installed of any material,
including plant materials, erected for the purpose of providing a boundary or
as a means of protection, or to prevent uncontrolled access, or for decorative
purposes (such as ornamental gate(s)), or to screen from view in or on
adjoining properties and streets, materials stored and operations conducted
behind it. Brushes, hedges and other organic configurations shall be regulated
as a fence if used as an enclosing structure or barrier, but shall not be
restricted in height unless such height creates a hazard or a nuisance.
   (C)   Height: The maximum height of a fence in a front yard shall be forty
eight inches (48"). The maximum height of a fence in a rear yard shall be six
feet (6') in residential and commercial zones; maximum eight feet (8') in
industrial zones.
   (D)   Location: Only open view fences shall be permitted in front yard
setback. Such fences may be located up to the property line in the front yard
setback including street/avenue side yard corner lots. (Ord. 13/2010, 5-3-2010)
   (E)   Double Fences: (Rep. by Ord. 13/2010, 5-3-2010)
   (F)   Design Standards:
      1.   All fences shall be of an architectural design that is common to the
community.
      2.   All fences shall be designed and constructed so as to be compatible
with its environment and surrounding properties from an architectural and
aesthetic standpoint.
      3.   No fence shall be of such architectural design or construction that
the same is manifestly inferior or is so radically different as to impair
marketability or property values of the existing property in the immediate
vicinity.
      4.   All fences shall be constructed with the finished, smooth or
decorative side facing toward adjoining properties.
      5.   All fences shall be constructed with the posts and supporting beams
facing the fence owner's property.
      6.   Uniform design and type shall be maintained along the entire fence
span.
      7.   All fences shall be structurally sound and be capable of carrying
the loads imposed upon them.
      8.   All fences shall be designed and constructed to resist a horizontal
wind load of not less than thirty five (35) pounds per square foot (psf) in
addition to any other forces to which it may be subjected.
      9.   Postholes for fences shall be in accordance with subsection (F)8 of
this section or per manufacturer's instructions. (Ord. 13/2010, 5-3-2010)
      10.   (Rep. by Ord. 13, 2010, 5-3-2010)
      11.   No fence shall have spikes, barbs or other pointed or sharp
assemblies. Top links shall be bent downward and uprights shall be of a design
so as to preclude accidental impalement on same.
      12.   Barbed or razor wire, or similar devices, shall only be allowed in
industrial districts upon receipt of special use approval as outlined in the
zoning ordinance.
      13.   Electrified fences are prohibited.
      14.   No fence, wall or shrubbery may be erected or maintained so as to
impede natural stormwater runoff, interfere with drainage of contiguous
properties or cause nuisance ponding, flooding or retention.
      15.   No fence shall cause a nuisance, hazard or otherwise adversely
affect the public health, safety and welfare. The building official shall
determine whether a particular set of circumstances, design or element
constitutes such condition. (Ord. 13/2010, 5-3-2010)
4-1-5: SWIMMING POOLS:
   (A)   A permit shall be required for all inground and semipermanent pools. A
permit is not required for a "temporary" pool.
   (B)   A "semipermanent pool" shall be defined as a swimming pool with a
steel wall or other substantial material that, once assembled, is designed to
remain in place over a period of two (2) or more swimming seasons.
   (C)   A "temporary" pool is defined as one that is inflated or otherwise
designed to be installed on a temporary basis and one that can be easily
drained and relocated. A "temporary" pool cannot be more than forty two inches
(42") in depth or it will be considered a "semipermanent" pool. (Ord. 06-19-06-
1, 8-21-2006)
4-1-6: PARKING LOTS:
   (A)   A permit shall be required for any new parking area, addition to
existing parking area or substantial renovation of existing parking area.
   (B)   "New parking area" is defined as any land area to be utilized for the
outdoor parking or storage of motor vehicles that has not, immediately prior to
the enactment of the regulation, been continuously utilized for such purpose.
(Exception: Accessory parking for one- and two-family dwellings.)
   (C)   Resurfacing of existing parking lots does not require permit or
compliance with construction standards. Standards for new parking lots for
religious and nonprofit organizations may be modified by the building official.
   (D)   Wheel stops are required where vehicles could strike buildings or
pedestrians, as determined by the building official.
   (E)   Lighting is required to provide adequate safety, but shall not create
nuisance to adjacent properties or surrounding neighborhood.
   (F)   Striping shall be required so as to identify spaces.
   (G)   Lot shall be graded so as to provide positive drainage. Lot drainage
shall not cause a hazard or a nuisance.
   (H)   Construction standards for new lots or additions to existing lots:

4-1-7: CONTRACTOR LICENSING:
   (A)   Application: Any contractor performing plumbing, electrical,
mechanical, subdivision, drain laying, sidewalk or road construction, roofing
and/or carpentry work in the City of Aledo shall obtain a City of Aledo
contractor license for such discipline(s). Applications for registration shall
be submitted to the Department of Public Works on forms provided by the
department along with the following:
      1.   A continuous surety bond made payable to the City of Aledo on a form
provided by the City in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with
sureties approved by the Director of Public Works or his/her designee,
conditioned that the applicant shall well and faithfully observe all the
provisions of the Building Code, Zoning Code and all other codes or regulations
of the City relating to the activities engaged in, under or by virtue of the
authority given in the building permit issued for each job, and that he will
pay all costs involved to complete said work and correct any and all work
improperly done to bring it into compliance with all City codes and
regulations. A minimum of thirty (30) days' notification must be provided to
the Department of Public Works before this bond may be canceled.
      2.   Proof of public liability and property damage insurance in the
minimum amount as hereby specified: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)
for each occurrence of property damage and three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) for each occurrence of personal injury or bodily harm. Such proof
shall be submitted in the form of an insurance certificate naming the City of
Aledo as an additional insured. A minimum of thirty (30) days' notification
must be provided to the Department of Public Works before this insurance may be
canceled.
      3.   Proof of workers' compensation insurance in the form of either a
certificate of insurance or certificate of approval as a self- insurer issued
by the Illinois Industrial Commission. Except: Applicants who operate his or
her business as a sole proprietor and have no employees are exempt from this
requirement. The applicant shall sign the registration application affirming
themselves as sole proprietor.
   (B)   Term Of License; Work Performed By: The license shall be in effect
from the time of issuance through December 31 of each calendar year and is
nontransferable. All work performed under permits issued by the City of Aledo
must be conducted by employees of the licensee covered under the insurance
listed above or by contractors registered in the City of Aledo. Subcontractors
operating under the permit obtained by the general contractor must also be
registered with the City of Aledo. Subcontractors must meet all the above
requirements. Work performed by these subcontractors may be subject to bonding
of the general contractor if specifically stated on the bond form, otherwise,
said subcontractor shall also supply a surety bond pursuant to the provisions
of this section. Any violations of the requirements of this registration or
failure to promptly repair work in violation of this or other adopted codes may
result in suspension or revocation of this registration at the discretion of
the building official. The registered contractor will be informed in writing by
the building official of any violations of this Code or other adopted codes and
he or she will be given a time frame to make the required corrections. This
notice is to be sent via certified mail, return receipt requested. The
contractor has the right to appeal the decision of the building official to the
Aledo Code Commission. The decision of the Code Commission may be appealed de
novo to the Chief Executive Officer of the City. All appeals shall be in
writing and presented to the building official not more than ten (10) days
after the notice was mailed.
      Exception: Owners who occupy their own single- or two-family dwelling who
perform their own work on such structures. Such owners shall assume all
liability for performance by himself or herself or their volunteers or
employees.
   State of Illinois Statutes do not allow any owner to hire any person or
persons to perform roofing work unless said person or persons has a current
Illinois roofing license nor to hire any person or persons to perform plumbing
work unless said person or persons possesses a current Illinois plumbing
license and is currently registered as an Illinois plumbing contractor.
   Owners of multi-family and all nonresidential buildings are required to
obtain a contractor license. Owners of such buildings shall also be required to
obtain the necessary State license to do their own roofing or plumbing work.
   (C)   General Maintenance: Persons doing general maintenance or cosmetic
work not requiring a permit shall not be required to be licensed.
   (D)   Additional Requirements:
      Plumbing: Shall also provide current State of Illinois plumber's license.
      Roofing: Shall also provide current State of Illinois roofing contractor
license. (Ord. 13/2017, 6-5-2017)
4-1-8: PERMIT FEES:
All permit fees are established and shall be payable to the City pursuant to
title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. (Ord. 13/2017, 6-5-2017)
4-1-9: PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE ENFORCEMENT:
For purpose of enforcing the ICC Property Maintenance Code, the following
policy shall be employed by the City of Aledo:
   (A)   The enforcement priority is on easily verifiable exterior yard
conditions, such as weeds in excess of eight inches (8") high, inoperable cars,
accumulations of junk, etc. Such enforcement shall be on a complaint basis, but
proactive enforcement may occur for significant nuisance violations and other
areas identified by the City Council (e.g., junk cars).
   (B)   Enforcement of exterior building conditions may occur if the violation
presents a significant blighting influence, nuisance, hazard or threat to life
safety. Such matters shall be primarily complaint driven, but may be proactive
if significant violation. The Enforcement Officer shall clear such enforcement
action with his or her Supervisor. If, for some reason, the enforcement action
is undertaken by the City Administrator, he shall discuss the matter with the
Mayor prior to undertaking such enforcement.
   (C)   Enforcement of interior violations may be conducted if the owner or
occupant of the building requests an inspection and subsequent enforcement.
Interior enforcement may also be attempted if there is reasonable and
sufficient cause to believe that a significant nuisance, hazard of threat to
life safety is occurring. Reasonable cause must exist to go forward with an
interior enforcement action. An example of a reasonable cause would be a foul
odor and rats coming from a building. The Enforcement Officer shall clear
interior enforcement action with his or her Supervisor. If, for some reason,
the enforcement action is undertaken by the City Administrator, he shall
discuss the matter with the Mayor prior to undertaking such enforcement.
   (D)   The Code Officer and all inspectors shall follow the regulation
provided in the Code about entrance on private property. The Code states that
permission shall be obtained before entering private property (other than
knocking at the door or entering a public area) and before conducting an
inspection. If permission is refused, the inspector shall leave the property
and obtain instruction from his Supervisor. Under no condition shall an
inspector violate a property owner's or occupant's Fourth Amendment right
against warrantless searches or seizures.
   (E)   The emphasis on Property Maintenance Code enforcement shall be
voluntary compliance. Courtesy notices shall be issued, reasonable extensions
granted where appropriate and all reasonable effort shall be made to work with
property owners rather than against them.
   (F)   No random inspection of properties shall occur unless they are
approved under the policies enumerated above. There shall be no program of
inspections, such as commercial occupancies or rental units, unless such are
specifically authorized by the City Council and regulated by written policies
and procedures.
   (G)   The City administration may cut weeds and remove accumulations of
garbage, refuse and salvageable or unsalvageable material after proper warning
period and all voluntary compliance measures have elapsed. Work shall be billed
to the property owner and thereafter placed as a lien. All State laws and
provisions of Code shall be complied with.
   (H)   The City administration may remove inoperable vehicles from private
property as provided for by State law and local policy. (Ord. 06-19-06-1, 8-21-
2006)
4-1-10: NEW OCCUPANCY REQUIREMENTS:
All new business occupancies and changes in use groups shall obtain a
certificate of occupancy from the building official prior to occupying property
for the new business or occupancy use. Such uses and occupancies shall comply
with the following process:
   (A)   Apply for certificate of occupancy (CO);
   (B)   Obtain an occupancy inspection from the Code Administration
Department;
   (C)   Correct all violations noted on inspection report, if any;
   (D)   Obtain reinspection approval from the Code Administration Department;
   (E)   Obtain and comply with certificate of occupancy;
   (F)   New businesses shall not occupy a building or premises until issued a
CO. A conditional CO may be issued at the building official's discretion,
depending on the severity of the violation and for other cause, such as
weather;
   (G)   This process shall not apply to home occupations. (Ord. 06-19-06-1, 8-
21-2006)
4-1-11: EXISTING BUSINESSES:
All businesses in operation as of the adoption date hereof shall be considered
to be existing businesses and not subject to the provisions of section
4-1-9 of this chapter. The City of Aledo shall establish a voluntary program
inviting existing businesses to:
   (A)   Submit annual application and obtain City license (no fee);
   (B)   Obtain annual fire safety and "housekeeping" inspection.
The City Council shall review the existing business licensing program after two
(2) years. (Ord. 06-19-06-1, 8-21-2006)
4-1-12: AWNINGS:
   (A)   Wooden Awnings Prohibited: Hereafter no wooden awning shall be erected
to any building within the fire limits of the City; nor shall any wooden awning
heretofore erected be repaired unless the same be covered or roofed with iron,
tin or other fireproof material and properly supported with iron posts. If not
constructed of wood, then it should be covered with cloth, leather or other
pliable substance or corrugated iron, securely attached to the building by iron
or other metallic fastenings or supports, and any and all awnings shall be
elevated at least seven feet (7') at the lowest part thereof above the
sidewalk. (Ord. 9/07, 3-16-1908; amd. Ord. 2/58, 5-5-1958; Ord. 06-19-06-1, 8-
21-2006)
   (B)   Posts Prohibited: All awnings hereafter erected or constructed in the
City extending over any street or public sidewalk shall be of canvas or of
metal and shall be so constructed or erected as not to be supported from the
ground surface or sidewalk level by posts, either wooden or metal or of any
other character. (Ord. 15/13, 4-6-1914; amd. Ord. 06-19-06-1, 8-21-2006)
   (C)   Duty Of Officers: It shall be the duty of the building official or his
designee to superintend or oversee the erection and repair of all awnings
within the fire limits of the City and if the same are not erected or repaired
in accordance with the provisions of this section, to serve notice upon the
person so erecting or repairing the same or upon the owner of the building to
which the respective awning is attached to erect or repair the same in
accordance with the provisions of this section or to remove the same for a
failure to comply with the same. (Ord. 6/91, 3-21-1992; amd. Ord. 06-19-06-1,
8-21-2006)
4-1-13: DRIVEWAYS; WALKS; CULVERTS:
   (A)   Specific Concrete Construction: Hereafter each and every concrete
driveway, sidewalk or other concrete construction, as to such part thereof
which may be laid or constructed upon any part of any public street or alley in
the City, which shall abut upon or adjoin to the concrete curbing of the street
pavement, or any part thereof, within the corporate limits of the City, as the
said curb is now or may hereafter be laid or constructed, shall be so laid or
constructed according to specifications to be provided by the building
official, after consultation with the City Engineer.
   (B)   Culverts: Upon request of a lot owner(s), the City shall pay for the
cost of installation for one culvert on each lot located within the City. Such
culvert shall not exceed twelve inches (12") in diameter and twenty feet (20')
in length. For all culverts in excess of twelve inches (12") in diameter and/or
twenty feet (20') in length, the City shall charge the requesting lot owner(s)
with the cost which exceeds the regular material and installation cost. The
City shall also charge a requesting lot owner(s) with the actual cost to
replace any such culvert on a lot located within the City unless otherwise
agreed to in writing between the City and the lot owner(s) as part of the
City's Culvert Replacement Program.
   (C)   Culvert Replacement Program: Lot owners may voluntarily participate in
the City's Culvert Replacement Program whereby the City will pay for fifty
percent (50%) of the actual cost to replace the lot owner(s)' culvert. The
annual program shall be from January 1 through December 31 each year, and shall
be administered on a first come, first serve basis and until such time that the
available program funds are exhausted each year. (Ord. 13/2017, 6-5-2017)
4-1-14: PENALTIES:
Unless otherwise stated, penalties upon conviction of an offense under this
chapter shall be as follows:
   (A)   Each violation at the property in question shall carry a fine pursuant
to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this Code.
   (B)   Other sanctions may be applied as provided for by law.
   (C)   The Hearing Officer may, in addition to the imposition of a fine,
order the defendant to perform community service unless otherwise precluded by
law.
   (D)   The imposition of fines shall not restrict the City from taking other
measures as provided by law to enforce this chapter and otherwise obtain
compliance or the abatement of nuisances. (Ord. 19/2016, 1-3-2017)
4-1-15: DEMOLITIONS:
   (A)   Permit: A permit shall be required for all demolitions, as defined.
   (B)   Definitions:
      DEMOLITION: The removal, in whole or part, of any structure or building,
the removal of demolition debris, or the installation of fill material and
final grading in connection with such removal.
      DEMOLITION CONTRACTOR: Any person or firm engaged in the business of
demolition of buildings or structures by contract.
      DIRECTOR: The Director of Public Works for the City or his authorized
agent.
   (C)   Demolition Standards:
      1.   All demolition work shall be carried out in safe and workman- like
manner to minimize hazard to adjacent property and the public.
      2.   All subterranean walls, floors and footings shall be removed.
      3.   All depressions, cavities, cisterns or wells shall be filled with
approved granular material or compacted structural clay to within six inches
(6") of final grade.
      4.   The final grading shall be such that no depressions or cavities
exist and stormwater cannot stand on the demolition site. Six inches (6") of
earth shall be installed over any depression, cavity, cistern or well filled
with fill material.
      5.   All debris resulting from demolition shall be removed from the site
where demolition occurs in a timely manner. In no event shall debris be used
for fill material.
      6.   Where necessary to protect public health and safety, the Director
may require the erection of fencing, barricades or protective canopies around
the perimeter of the demolition site.
      7.   No demolition work shall be conducted between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. unless previously approved by
the Director.
      8.   Streets, roadways and alleys adjacent to a demolition site may be
closed only after approval by the Director. The Director shall, prior to
approval of such closing, consult with the Fire Chief, Police Chief and
Director of City Services.
      9.   It is the responsibility of the owner or his agent to arrange the
disconnection of all utilities to a demolition site prior to demolition. All
water, sewer and gas lines shall be properly capped and sealed. Sewer lines
shall be disconnected in accordance with the requirements established in title
8, chapter 6 of this Code.
      10.   In the event the structure to be demolished has one or more party
walls, the applicant shall provide drawings sealed by a registered architect or
structural engineer indicating the measures to be taken to support the adjacent
structures after demolition. In the event adjacent structures do not require
additional support, the architect or engineer shall provide a written statement
stating such conclusion. The written consent of owners of adjacent buildings to
install necessary shoring or bracing shall be provided. (Ord. 13/2017, 6-5-
2017)

5-1-1: LIMITS ESTABLISHED:
Hereafter all that portion of the city within and bounded as follows:
Commencing at the southwest corner of Block Eighty-six (86) in the Original
Town, now City of Aledo, running thence north to the south line of Lot Three
(3) in said Block Eighty-six (86), thence East along the south line of said Lot
Three in Block Eighty Six, Sixty Feet, thence north to the north line of said
Lot Three, thence West to the Northwest corner of said Lot Three, thence North
to the southwest corner of Block Seventy-five, thence west along the north line
of Sixth (6th) Street to the southwest corner of Block Seventy-six (76), thence
north along the east line of Locust Street to the northwest corner of Lot Six
(6) in Block Sixty-five (65), thence east to the southwest corner of Lot Three
(3) in Block Sixty-six (66), thence north along the east side of Walnut Street
to the northwest corner of Block Sixty-six (66), thence along the south side of
Eighth (8th) Street to the northwest corner of Lot One (1) of Block Sixty-seven
(67), thence south to the southwest corner of Lot One (1) in Block Sixty-seven
(67), thence east to the southeast corner of Lot One (1) in Block Sixty-eight
(68), thence south along the west line of Spruce Street to the southeast corner
of Fractional Block Three (3) in the Original Town of Aledo, thence west along
the north line of Fifth (5th) Street to the place of beginning, is hereby
established and declared to be the Fire Limits of the City, and to embrace and
include the south half of Block Sixty-five (65), all of Block Sixty-six (66),
seven-eights of Block Sixty-seven, Seventy-five (75), Seventy-six (76), Eighty-
six (86), Fractional Blocks Three (3) and Four (4), and the south three-fourths
(3/4) of Block Sixty-eight (68), in the original plat of the City of Aledo, and
Blocks Three (3) and Four (4) in Thompson's Railroad Addition to the City.
(Ord. 7/11, 10-2-1911)
5-1-2: BUILDING REGULATIONS:
All buildings shall not be erected, enlarged or added to within the fire limits
unless the same conform to the requirements and specifications and provisions
of the building code as provided in section
4-1-1 of this code. (Ord. 15/1900, 4-17-1901)
CHAPTER 2
FIRE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-2-1:   Open Burning
5-2-2:   Gasoline
5-2-3:   Fire Escapes
5-2-4:   Lumber In Fire Limits
5-2-1: OPEN BURNING:
No person shall cause or permit, except as herein stipulated, any open air,
open fire burning of any item within the fire or corporate limits. It shall
also be unlawful to burn any wastepaper or other inflammable waste matter,
within the fire limits of the city, except the same be burned in some suitable
iron or steel, or other substantial metal receptacle, or furnace, which shall
be provided with grating under the entire surface of the bottom thereof, and
with a substantial metal screen or covering over the top so constructed as to
not allow the escape from such receptacle of any partially burned particles of
such paper or other inflammable waste matter, or any cinders or sparks of
sufficient size to constitute a fire menace to property. Such receptacle or
furnace shall be compliant with the application regulations of the Illinois
environmental protection agency.
   (A)   Definitions:
      COMBUSTIBLE REFUSE: Any combustible waste material.
      HAZARD: Smoke, heat, flames or other condition generated by an open air,
open fire that presents a clear, significant threat to the health, safety or
welfare of the general public.
      NUISANCE: Smoke, heat, flames or other condition caused by open air, open
fires that unreasonably interferes with a right that is common to the general
public.
      OPEN AIR: All spaces outside buildings, stacks or exterior ducts.
      OPEN FIRE: Any fire from which the products of combustion are emitted
directly into the open air without passing through a stack or chimney. (Ord.
10-20-08-1, 11-3-2008)
   (B)   Exceptions:
      1.   This provision shall not be construed to prohibit fires of charcoal
or nontreated or otherwise nonnuisance or nonhazard producing wood or wood
product when utilized on private property or in public recreation areas
relative to the consumption of food.
      2.   Nothing in this section shall be held to prohibit private
individuals from setting a wood burning campfire for the purpose of the
preparation of food or other accessory recreational use incidental to the
primary, lawful use of the property in question; provided, such campfire is set
in an adequate container assembled or premanufactured for such use and, if
premanufactured, set according to manufacturer's specifications, or, a fire
bowl of earth or other noncombustible of adequate assembly and construction,
and, a minimum distance of ten feet (10') from weeds, grass or other
combustible materials so as to present no hazard. Such fires shall also be
placed a minimum of twenty feet (20') from adjacent residences and attended at
all times by a person of eighteen (18) years of age or older.
      3.   It shall be lawful to burn leaves, grass or other vegetation so long
as such materials are dry and do not produce a nuisance or a hazard; provided,
however, that burning of such yard waste shall be permitted on Monday,
Wednesday, Thursday, and Saturday only. It is unlawful for any person to burn
any leaves or other vegetation upon any city street, city sidewalk or in that
portion of the right of way three feet (3') from the edge of the street
pavement. All such fires shall be attended at all times by a person of eighteen
(18) years of age or older. Such fires shall be permitted during daylight hours
only and shall not be placed within twenty feet (20') of adjacent residences.
      4.   Bonfires for the purpose of public or private school activities
shall be permitted on school grounds and as further regulated by the Aledo fire
protection district. (Ord. 03/2012, 4-2-2012)
   (C)   Penalties: Any person who violates this section shall be fined
pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this code. (Ord. 20/2016, 1-3-
2017)
5-2-2: GASOLINE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any store or shop keeper or other person or
persons doing business to keep on hand at any time for sale or use any amount
or quantity exceeding two (2) barrels of gasoline in any house, building or
storeroom or in any shed or other place connected with, or attached to any such
house, building or storeroom within the corporate limits of the city. It shall
further be unlawful for any store or shop keeper or other person as aforesaid
keeping gasoline to draw or permit to be drawn or changed from one vessel to
another, any quantity of gasoline by the aid of any lighted lamp, candle, or
other burning substance used for illuminating purposes, held or being in the
vicinity of the vessels from and to which gasoline is being drawn or filled,
and when so drawn into other vessels for sale in the line of trade or for any
other purpose, it shall be unlawful for such shop or store keeper to leave or
permit any such vessel to be left standing over two (2) hours in, upon or about
the premises, room or place wherein such sale is made, except in the room or
house wherein such gasoline was drawn.
It shall be unlawful for any person or family residing or rooming within the
fire limits of the city, using gasoline stoves for cooking, or other purposes,
to keep the vessel containing the supply of gasoline inside any room or
apartment of the building in which such person or family reside or use. (Ord.
7/87, 8-1-1887)
   (B)   No public filling station or other place or edifice wherein oils and
gasoline, or either of them, are kept and retailed to the public shall be
established, maintained or operated without the consent of the council so to do
being first obtained. The council shall in no case consent to the
establishment, maintenance or operation of a filling station as above defined
outside of the fire limits of the city unless application for such permission
shall be accompanied by a petition of consent signed by a majority of the
property owners within a radius of two hundred feet (200') of a point located
in the center of the space actually used as a filling station. Said petition of
consent shall request that permission be granted by the council to the
applicant therein mentioned. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply
to filling stations or garages already established, or to wholesale or retail
groceries maintained and operated as such, or to persons or places where oil
and gasoline are sold by wholesale only. (Ord. 9/29, 10-7-1929)
5-2-3: FIRE ESCAPES:
All buildings within the city limits which are more than two (2) stories in
height used for manufacturing purposes, hotels, dormitories, schools,
seminaries, hospitals, churches, theaters, public halls and lodge halls shall
be provided with at least one metallic ladder or stair fire escape, attached to
the outer walls thereof and extending from or suitably near the ground, to the
uppermost story and provided with platforms of such form and dimensions and of
such proximity to one or more windows of each story above the first or ground
floor, as to render access to such ladder or stairs from each such story easy
and safe, the material, location and construction of such escapes shall be
subject to the approval of the fire and water committee of the city; provided,
however, that all buildings within the limits of the city used for any of the
above named purposes with a seating or working capacity above the second floor
shall be provided with one such ladder or stairs above mentioned for each one
hundred (100) persons or fraction thereof for which working or seating
accommodations are provided and be subject to the approval of said committee.
Any building used for any of the above named purposes with a seating or working
capacity on the first or ground floor only shall have at least two (2) doors
and on opposite sides of the building, and no door shall be less than two feet
ten inches (2'10") in width and shall have at least one aisle for every twenty
five feet (25') in width of seating capacity. No aisle in any building used for
the above named purposes shall be less than two feet (2') in width and no
corridor less than two feet (2') wide. All aisles, passageways and corridors
shall be kept free from obstructions, and no person shall be allowed to stand
in or occupy any of said aisles, passageways or corridors during any
performance or public gathering. (Ord. 6/03, 2-2-1904)
5-2-4: LUMBER IN FIRE LIMITS:
   (A)   No lumberyard or other place where lumber is stored for sale, shall be
permitted within the fire limits of the city. (Ord. 7/10, 8-8-1910)
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or pile for the purpose
of storage, sale, retail or use, any timbers, boards, joists, scantlings,
shingles, fencing, laths, pickets, posts, poles, coal, slack, firewood, or any
other combustible material, or any sand, gravel or other building material,
upon any lot, block or other grounds, either public or private, situated within
the fire limits of the city; provided, however, that lumbermen, architects,
contractors and builders or other persons receiving shipments of lumber,
building material, wood or wooden material in any form, or coal, coke or slack
or other combustible materials, or any sand, gravel or other building
materials, contemplated in this section, may upon receiving any such materials
from any common carrier, pile or store the same temporarily within said fire
limits, for such time only as may reasonably be necessary to promptly remove
the same for use, where the same may be unloaded, as hereinafter provided.
   (C)   Lumbermen, architects, builders, or other persons so receiving any
such combustible materials as in this section defined, shall be required to
remove the same to some point outside of the fire limits within five (5) days
after each carload shall have been discharged. (Ord. 2/14, 7-6-1914)
CHAPTER 3
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
5-3-1:   Definitions
5-3-2:   Prohibition
5-3-3:   Abatement
5-3-4:   Destruction By Fire
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS: As used in this chapter is hereby defined to mean and
include:
   (A)   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which is
dangerous to the public health because of its condition, and which may cause or
aid in the spread of disease, or injury to the health of the occupants of it or
neighboring structures.
   (B)   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which because of
faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is
especially liable to fire and constitutes a fire hazard.
   (C)   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which by reason
of faulty construction or any other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage
by collapsing or by a collapse or fall of any part of such structure.
   (D)   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which because of
its condition or because of lack of doors or windows is available to and
frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of
such structure, or by reason of its condition and lack of doors and windows
constitutes an attractive nuisance.
Any dangerous building in the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (Ord.
8/54, 7-19-1954)
5-3-2: PROHIBITION:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous
building in the city, and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or
person in custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a
dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied
while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. (Ord. 8/54, 7-19-1954)
5-3-3: ABATEMENT:
Whenever the zoning enforcing officer or the fire chief shall be of the opinion
that any building or structure in the city is a dangerous building, he shall
file a written statement to this effect with the clerk. The clerk shall
thereupon cause written notice to be served on the owner thereof, and upon the
occupant thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such
notices shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous
condition, and that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by
repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it; and that the condition
must be remedied at once. Such notice may be in the following terms: (Ord. 8/
54, 7-19-1954; amd. Ord. 05/2014, 4-7-2014)
To                      (owner-occupant of premises) of the premises known as:
                    : You are hereby notified that (describe building) on the
premises above mentioned has been condemned as a nuisance and a dangerous
building after inspection by                   .
 
The causes for this decision are:                           (here insert the
facts as to the dangerous condition).
 
You must remedy this condition or demolish the building immediately, or the
City will proceed to do so.
If the person receiving the notice has not complied therewith or taken an
appeal from the determination of the officer or employee finding that a
dangerous building exists, within ten (10) days from the time when such notice
is served upon such person by personal service or registered mail, the council
may proceed to remedy the condition or demolish the dangerous building. (Ord.
8/54, 7-19-1954)
5-3-4: DESTRUCTION BY FIRE:
Any building or structure within the fire limits which has or may be damaged by
fire, wind, decay or other causes to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its
value, shall be torn down and removed, or rebuilt under the regulations of the
zoning title and the requirements within the fire limits of the city.
Upon written notice by the zoning enforcing officer or the fire chief to the
effect that any such building has been so damaged, filed with the clerk, the
said clerk shall notify the council of the receipt of such notice.
The council shall then appoint three (3) persons to determine whether or not
such building or structure has been damaged to the extent of fifty percent
(50%) of its value.
A copy of the notice of the appointment of this board of three (3) persons to
determine the damage shall be served upon the owner of the premises by personal
service or by registered mail addressed to his last known address. Such notice
shall be in substantially the following form: (Ord. 05/2014, 4-7-2014)
To                                 You are hereby notified that
                         has determined that the building owned by you within
the corporate limits of the City of Aledo has been damaged by fire, decay or
otherwise to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its value and that a board of
three persons, has been appointed to verify this finding which board will hold
its first meeting in the council room of the City Hall in the City of Aledo,
Illinois, on the                 day of                  , 19    , at the hour
of             o'clock,     , at which time it will determine whether or not
this finding is correct.
 
If the finding is verified by the Board, you must tear down and remove the said
building, or rebuild it in accordance with the Zoning regulations and the
requirements within the fire limits of said City of Aledo.
 
If this finding is verified by the board of three (3) members and it determines
that the building in question has been damaged to the extent of fifty percent
(50%) of its value, it shall be the duty of the owner to tear down and remove
the said building within twenty (20) days after the finding of such board, or
to remodel it to comply with the requirements for new buildings in accordance
with the zoning regulations and the requirements within said fire limits of the
city; and it shall be unlawful to occupy or permit the occupancy of such
building after such finding until it is so remodeled. (Ord. 8/54, 7-19-1954)
CHAPTER 4
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
SECTION:
5-4-1:   Adoption Of Fire Prevention Code
5-4-1: ADOPTION OF FIRE PREVENTION CODE:
There is hereby adopted for the purpose of fire protection, acceptable
construction, and building service features needed to minimize danger from fire
and smoke in new and existing structures in all types of occupancies in the
city of Aledo the NFPA 101 life safety code being the 2000 edition. (Ord. 15/
2004, 12-6-2004)
TITLE 6
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
POLICE
SECTION:
6-1-1:   Department Established
6-1-2:   Appointment
6-1-3:   Powers
6-1-4:   Duty To Arrest
6-1-5:   Preserve Peace
6-1-6:   Members' Duties
6-1-7:   Neglect Of Duty
6-1-8:   Regulations Of Department
6-1-9:   Part Time Police Officers
6-1-10:   Auxiliary Police Officers
6-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a department of the City to be known as the Police
Department and which shall consist of the Chief of Police and such other
officers and members as recommended by the Police Committee of the Council and
approved by the Council. (1969 Code)
6-1-2: APPOINTMENT:
The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Council upon the recommendation
of the Police Committee and shall hold his office from and after his
appointment until discharged by order of the Council. He shall, before entering
upon the duties of his office, take and sign the oath prescribed by law for
City officials. All other police officers shall be appointed in accordance with
the provisions of chapter 24, article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code. (1969
Code)
6-1-3: POWERS:
The Chief of Police shall superintend and direct the police generally and see
that the various police officers are prompt in the discharge of their duties,
and from time to time adopt such measures as they may deem expedient for the
preservation of the peace and good order of the City and the prompt execution
of the laws and ordinances thereof. The Chief of Police and Police Committee
with the concurrence of the Council, may, and they are hereby authorized and
required to make and establish such rules and regulations, not inconsistent
with the laws of the State or the City, as may by them be hereafter deemed
expedient and necessary for the management and control of the Police
Department, and with a view to the vigilance, efficiency and usefulness of the
Police Department and the orderly conduct of its members. (7-28-1879)
6-1-4: DUTY TO ARREST:
The Chief of Police and Council and all police officers shall have power to
arrest, or cause to be arrested and taken before the proper court or Magistrate
with or without process, all persons in said City who shall be found in the act
of committing, or who may reasonably be suspected of having committed any crime
or misdemeanor, or violated any provision hereof, and all persons who shall
threaten to break the peace; and shall have power to detain, or order the
detention of such person or persons overnight, and until such person or persons
can be duly examined or tried before the proper court or Magistrate. (7-28-
1879; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-1-5: PRESERVE PEACE:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and Police Committee to cause the
public peace to be preserved, and to see that all the laws and ordinances of
the City are enforced; and whenever any violation thereof shall come to their
knowledge they shall cause the requisite complaint to be made, and see that the
evidence is procured for the prosecution of such offender. They shall obey, and
cause all the police officers subordinate to them to obey all laws and
ordinances regulating the police, and the police regulations which may
hereafter at any time be established by the Chief of Police and the Council and
the Police Committee, and see that the police respectively perform their duties
faithfully and promptly. (7-28-1879)
6-1-6: MEMBERS' DUTIES:
All members of the department acting as police officers are required to be
prompt and vigilant in the discharge of their duties in their respective
stations, according to the laws and ordinances of the City, and provisions of
such police regulations as may be hereafter established, and shall, to the best
of their ability, preserve order, peace and quiet, and enforce the provisions
of this Code, and shall not absent themselves from the City or from the duties
assigned them respectively, unless by the permission of the Chief of Police, or
the Police Committee (in his absence) had in writing. (7-28-1879; amd. Ord. 22/
2017, 6-19-2017)
6-1-7: NEGLECT OF DUTY:
Any police officer who shall neglect or refuse to perform any duty assigned to,
or required of him by law or any provision of this Code, or who shall in the
discharge of his official duties, be guilty of any fraud, extortion, partially
or wilful wrong or injustice, shall, on conviction of such offense, forfeit and
pay for the use of said City, a penalty; and if a watchman, shall be dismissed
from his office. (7-28-1879; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-1-8: REGULATIONS OF DEPARTMENT:
All such police regulations as may hereafter be established shall be in
writing, signed by the Chief of Police; and he shall cause the same to be filed
in the Clerk's Office, and a written or printed copy thereof to be delivered to
each member of the Police Department, and by which rules and regulations they
shall respectively be governed in the performance of their duties, when not
conflicting with the provisions of this Code. (7-28-1879; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-
19-2017)
6-1-9: PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
   (A)   The City of Aledo Police Department is hereby authorized to employ
part time police officers, subject to the requirements set forth in this
section.
   (B)   No individual shall be hired as a part time police officer for the
City of Aledo Police Department unless such individual satisfies each of the
requirements enumerated herein. In order to qualify for part time employment as
a police officer with the City of Aledo Police Department, an applicant must:
      1.   Be a citizen of the United States;
      2.   Be twenty one (21) years of age;
      3.   Be a high school graduate or equivalent;
      4.   Possess a valid Illinois driver's license;
      5.   Possess or obtain at time of hire a current Illinois firearms owner
identification card;
      6.   Have no felony criminal record, and if a misdemeanor criminal
record, a copy of the record shall be submitted with the written application
required in subsection (B)11 of this section and an explanation if required by
the Chief of Police to explain all circumstances;
      7.   Submit fingerprints for examination by the Illinois State Police
Bureau of Identification and Federal Bureau of Investigation;
      8.   Submit to a physical examination, at the expense of the City of
Aledo, and be found drug free;
      9.   Submit to a psychological examination, at the expense of the City of
Aledo;
      10.   Submit to an oral interview before the Chief of Police;
      11.   Submit a written application and/or resume to the Chief of Police;
      12.   Be qualified to enter and successfully complete any training
mandated by the Illinois Law Enforcement Standards and Training Board, or have
sufficient prior experience and training to qualify for a waiver from the
Illinois Law Enforcement Standards and Training Board. (Ord. 09/2011, 7-5-2011;
amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
   (C)   Part time police officers shall be allowed to work no more than a
maximum of one thousand five hundred sixty (1,560) hours per calendar year.
(Ord. 19/2011, 10-17-2011; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-1-10: AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS:
   (A)   Authorization: The City of Aledo Police Department is hereby
authorized to appoint auxiliary police officers, subject to the requirements
set forth in this section.
   (B)   Appointment: The Chief of Police may appoint auxiliary police officers
in such number as the department may from time to time deem necessary.
   (C)   Status: Auxiliary police officers shall not be "conservators of the
peace" unless they have completed the basic police officer academy training 1 ,
and shall only carry firearms while on duty with the permission of the Chief of
Police, and only after completing the State certified 40-hour mandatory
firearms training course as provided under 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 710/2.
Auxiliary police officers shall not be considered to be members of the regular
Police Department, and shall not supplement members of the regular Police
Department of the City in the performance of their assigned and normal duties
except as otherwise provided herein.
   (D)   Identification Symbol: Identification symbols worn by the auxiliary
police officers shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular
Police Department.
   (E)   Supervision: Auxiliary police officers shall, at all times during the
performance of their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the
Chief of Police of the City of Aledo.
   (F)   Powers And Duties: Auxiliary police officers shall only be assigned to
perform the following duties in the City:
      1.   To receive training from regular members of the department,
      2.   To aid or direct traffic within the Municipality,
      3.   To aid in control of natural or man-made disasters,
      4.   To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the Chief of Police,
      5.   To assist regular members of the department under the direct
supervision of those regular members,
      6.   To aid in crowd control, parking control and event control during
events and periods leading up to events sponsored by the City of Aledo or held
within the City of Aledo, and,
      7.   When it is impractical for members of the regular Police Department
to perform normal and regular police duties, the Chief of Police may assign
auxiliary police officers to perform those normal and regular police duties
under the direct supervision of a regular member of the Police Department.
   (G)   Hiring Standards: No person shall be hired as an auxiliary police
officer who has not been fingerprinted, subject to a background check, and
found to have never been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral
turpitude.
   (H)   Training: All officers hired as auxiliary police officers shall
successfully complete the Auxiliary Officer Field Training Program. (Ord. 06/
2019, 3-4-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 705/8.2.
CHAPTER 2
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
6-2-1:   Purpose
6-2-2:   Definitions
6-2-3:   Exclusions; Exceptions
