6-2-11-8:   Dogs Prohibited In Public Areas On Certain Days
6-2-12:   Dog Park Regulations
6-2-13:   Penalty
6-2-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect and promote the public health, safety
and general welfare of the city by establishing requirements for the effective
control of animals. This chapter is in addition to, and does not preempt, the
state of Illinois animal control act, humane care of animals, animal welfare
act, and the state and federal wildlife codes. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff.
1-1-2016)
6-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   ADULT DOG OR CAT: A dog or cat four (4) months of age or older.
   ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: Any person designated by the city to enforce the
rules and regulations established under this chapter. This authority also
extends to Aledo police officers to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
   CAT: All members of the genus Felis.
   DANGEROUS DOG:
   (A)   Any individual dog anywhere other than upon the property of the owner
or custodian of the dog and unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended by its owner or
custodian that behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe poses
a serious and unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death
to a person or a companion animal, or
   (B)   A dog that, without justification, bites a person and does not cause
serious physical injury.
   DOG: All members of the family Canidae.
   ENCLOSURE: A building or other structure strong enough to keep the confined
animal away from other animals and the public.
   EXOTIC ANIMAL: Any monkey, primate, raccoon, skunk, fox, poisonous snake,
python snake, boa constrictor snake, piranha fish, leopard, panther, tiger,
lion, lynx, bears or any other warm blooded animal which can normally be found
in the wild state.
   HAS BEEN BITTEN: Has been seized with the teeth or jaws so that the person
or animal seized has been nipped, gripped, wounded or pierced, and further
includes contact of saliva with any break or abrasion of the skin.
   LEASH: A cord, rope, strap or chain which shall be securely fastened to the
collar or harness of a dog and of sufficient strength to keep such dog under
control, and no more than eight feet (8') in length.
   OWNER: Any person having a right or property in a dog or other animal, or
who keeps or harbors a dog or other animal, or who has it in his or her care,
or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits a dog or other domestic
animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him or her.
   PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association or legal
entity, any public or private institution, or any other business unit.
   POLICE DOG: A dog owned or used by a law enforcement department or agency in
the course of the department's or agency's work. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff.
1-1-2016)
6-2-3: EXCLUSIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
6-2-3-1: EXCLUSIONS:
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter do not apply to: veterinary hospitals,
properly licensed boarding kennels, pet shops, animal shelters, properly
maintained and licensed zoological park, circus, scientific education institute
or research laboratory.
   (B)   The provisions of this chapter do not apply to police dogs.
   (C)   The provisions of this chapter do not affect the extermination of
rats, mice, moles or voles. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-3-2: EXCEPTIONS:
   (A)   Upon a proper showing therefor, and upon due and convincing proof
being made to the City Council of unique and unusual circumstances under which
the strict enforcement of this chapter would result in extreme and peculiar
hardship for the person involved, the Council may grant special permission to
the person to do some act contrary to section
6-2-7, 6-2-8-1 or 6-2-8-4 of this chapter. The Council shall presume that such
a hardship exists for any person who: 1) makes application for special
permission under this subsection within ninety (90) days following passage of
this chapter, and 2) provides proof that on the date of adoption hereof, and
for a period of at least ninety (90) days prior thereto, such person either: a)
maintained animals in apparent violation of section
6-2-7 of this chapter, b) owned more than six (6) cats or dogs in violation of
section
6-2-8-1 of this chapter, or c) maintained a doghouse, shelter, kennel, dog run
or other structure in violation of section
6-2-8-4 of this chapter.
   (B)   The granting of any special permission may be approved by the City
Council only after a public hearing has been held by the Council.
   (C)   A legal notice shall be published at least one time in a newspaper of
general circulation within the corporate limits of the City. The notice shall
set forth the nature of the public hearing, the property involved and the date,
time and place of the scheduled hearing, and shall be published at least five
(5) calendar days prior to the hearing date. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-
1-2016)
   (D)   Any request for special permission shall be accompanied by a fee
pursuant to title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. (Ord. 14/2017, 6-5-
2017)
   (E)   In addition to the legal notice, the Aledo Police Department shall
post a sign on the property for which special permission is being requested not
less than five (5) calendar days prior to the hearing date. The sign shall give
notice of the special permission being requested and the date, time and place
of the scheduled hearing. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-4: INTERFERENCE:
It shall be a violation of this chapter to interfere with the animal control
officer in the performance of his or her duties. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff.
1-1-2016)
6-2-5: NOISE DISTURBANCE:
No person shall own, keep or harbor any animal which howls, barks, or emits
audible sounds that are unreasonably loud or disturbing and which are of such
character, intensity and duration as to disturb the peace and quiet of the
neighborhood or such resident or business neighbors as may be in close
proximity to such animal. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-6: MAINTENANCE:
   (A)   Removal Of Waste Material: It shall be unlawful for any person having
control of any dog or other animal which deposits any solid excrement or feces
upon any public way, sidewalk, street or right-of-way, or upon the property of
another, without the consent of the property owner, to leave said excrement or
feces without causing its immediate and complete removal.
   (B)   Premises To Be Clean: The owner of any animal or fowl shall maintain
the premises wherein the animals or fowl are kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, free from rodents, vermin and waste and any odors that can be
detected beyond the limits of the owner's premises.
   (C)   Food And Water: The owner of any animal or fowl shall provide food and
water of adequate quality and quantity for animals or fowl in accordance with
the needs of the animals or fowl.
   (D)   Shelter: The owner of any animal or fowl shall provide adequate
shelter from the elements for the animal or fowl. For those animals or fowl
which are kept out of doors, adequate shelter shall be a structure with a top
and enclosed sides, except for an opening large enough for the passage of the
animal or fowl.
   (E)   Veterinary Care: The owner of any animal or fowl shall, when necessary
to prevent suffering of the animal or fowl, provide veterinary care for the
animal or fowl.
   (F)   Impoundment Authorized: The animal control officer is hereby
authorized to remove from any premises and impound any animal or fowl, the
owner of which has not complied with any or all of the requirements under this
section. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-7: ANIMALS OTHER THAN DOGS AND CATS:
6-2-7-1: LIVESTOCK:
No person shall keep or maintain any horse, mule, pony, donkey, burro, cow,
goat, sheep or pig within the corporate limits of the City unless the animal is
situated on a tract of ground at least two (2) acres in area, and the pen,
shed, barn, stable or other structure designed to confine or shelter the animal
is so located on the tract that the nearest portion thereof is not less than
one hundred fifty feet (150') from the line of adjoining property. (Ord. 8/
2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-7-2: FOWL:
A person may keep or maintain any mature chicken, turkey, duck, goose, guinea,
pigeon or other poultry or fowl within the corporate limits of the City in
accordance with the following provisions:
   (A)   A maximum of fifteen (15) fowl shall be permitted on any property.
Roosters shall be prohibited.
   (B)   No pen, coop, building or other enclosure used for the purpose of
housing fowl shall be erected or maintained within ten feet (10') of a property
line or within twenty feet (20') of any occupied residence other than that of
the owner.
   (C)   Every person maintaining a pen, coop, building, yard or enclosure for
fowl shall keep such area clean and sanitary at all times. Any dirt or refuse
resulting from the fowl shall be disposed of in a clean and sanitary fashion.
   (D)   All feed for fowl or livestock shall be kept in containers that are
rodentproof until put out for consumption by fowl. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015,
eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-7-3: RABBITS:
No person shall keep or maintain more than eight (8) mature rabbits six (6)
months of age or more within the corporate limits of the City; and no pen,
hutch or other structure designed to confine or shelter a rabbit or rabbits
shall be so located that any portion of the pen, hutch or other structure is
closer than ten feet (10') from the line of adjoining property. (Ord. 8/2015,
10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-7-4: EXOTIC ANIMALS:
No person shall keep or maintain any exotic animal as a pet within the
corporate limits of the City. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-7-5: RIDING OF HORSES ON CITY STREETS:
   (A)   A person may ride a horse on the streets of the City provided the
horse is ridden at less than a gallop, and the horse does not obstruct the flow
of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. No more than one person shall ride the
horse at any time. The horse shall be controlled by a bridle and reins. The
horse shall be under the control of the rider at all times.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any horse to allow the horse to
defecate on any public sidewalk, thoroughfare, public place, or private
property other than the premises owned or occupied by the owner of the horse.
(Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-8: DOGS AND CATS GENERALLY:
6-2-8-1: KEEPING OF DOGS AND CATS:
It is unlawful to maintain or keep more than six (6) adult dogs or cats, or any
combination thereof, in or about any dwelling unit, whether indoors or outside.
(Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-2-8-2: RABIES INOCULATION:
No person shall permit any adult dog or cat owned by him or her or in his or
her custody or control to be on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other
public place, or upon the private property of any person other than the owner,
unless the dog or cat shall have a collar firmly attached around its neck with
a tag evidencing a current rabies inoculation attached thereto. Any person
owning or having in his or her custody or control a dog or cat which does not
have a collar firmly attached around its neck with a tag evidencing a current
rabies inoculation shall keep the dog or cat confined in an enclosure in or on
his or her premises at all times. This does not eliminate the requirements for
rabies inoculation. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-8-3: DOGS OR CATS IN HEAT:
The owner of any female dog or cat shall, during the period when the female is
in heat, keep the female confined in an enclosure in such a manner so that the
female cannot come into contact with male dogs or cats, except for the purpose
of planned breeding. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-8-4: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
No doghouse, shelter, kennel, dog run or other structure used to house dogs
shall be so located so that any portion of the doghouse, shelter, kennel, dog
run or other structure that houses dogs is closer than ten feet (10') from the
line of the adjoining property. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-8-5: PROCEDURE WHEN ANIMAL BITES ANY PERSON:
   (A)   The owner of any dog, cat or other animal which bites any human being
shall notify the animal control officer within twenty four (24) hours; the
owner shall provide proof of rabies inoculation and registration to the animal
control officer; shall keep the dog, cat or other animal locked up in an
enclosure for a period of ten (10) days following the time the dog, cat or
other animal has bitten a person; and shall have the dog, cat or other animal
examined by a licensed veterinarian at the beginning and end of the ten (10)
day period. The owner of the biting animal shall provide a written release
signed and dated by a licensed veterinarian to the animal control officer
within twenty four (24) hours of release.
   (B)   When a person has been bitten by a police dog, the police dog may
continue to perform its duties for the peace officer or Law Enforcement Agency
and any period of observation of the police dog may be under the supervision of
a peace officer. The supervision shall consist of the dog being locked in a
kennel, performing its official duties in a police vehicle, or remaining under
the constant supervision of its police handler. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff.
1-1-2016)
   (C)   If a dog or other animal without provocation, bites or injures any
person who is peaceably conducting himself or herself in any place where he or
she may lawfully be, the owner of such dog or other animal shall be in
violation hereof. (Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-2-9: DANGEROUS AND VICIOUS DOGS:
6-2-9-1: PROCEDURE FOR DECLARING A DOG DANGEROUS:
   (A)   An animal control officer or any adult person may request, under oath,
that a dog be classified as a dangerous dog by submitting a sworn, written
complaint on a form approved by the animal control officer. In addition, in any
instance where the animal control officer has reasonable grounds to believe
that a dog has bitten a person or a domestic animal, an investigation as
hereinafter described shall be conducted. Upon receipt of the complaint, the
officer shall notify the owner of the dog that a complaint has been filed and
that an investigation into the allegations as set forth in the complaint will
be conducted. During the investigation:
      1.   The custody of any dog which is the subject of the investigation
shall not be transferred by its owner to any other person; nor shall the place
of maintenance of the dog be changed from its owner's residence during that
time, without the consent of the animal control officer; and
      2.   In addition, the dog may be ordered impounded by the animal control
officer if he or she has reason to believe that during the investigation the
dog will cause an immediate danger to the community if it is not immediately
impounded. The owner may appeal the impoundment order to the Chief of Police at
any time by filing a written appeal with the Aledo Police Department. The Chief
of Police, or his or her designee, shall give the owner a hearing within three
(3) business days of the filing of the appeal.
   (B)   At the conclusion of the investigation, the officer may:
      1.   Determine that the dog is not dangerous and, if the dog is
impounded, waive any impoundment fees incurred and release the dog to its
owner; or
      2.   Determine that the dog is dangerous and, if the dog is impounded,
release the dog to the owner after the owner has paid all fees incurred for the
impoundment. If all impoundment fees have not been paid within ten (10)
business days after a final determination that a dog is dangerous, the officer
may cause the dog to be humanely destroyed; or
      3.   Determine that the dog is vicious, in which case the provisions of
section
6-2-9-3 of this chapter shall apply.
   (C)   1. Within five (5) business days after declaring a dog dangerous, the
officer shall notify the owner of the dog's designation as a dangerous dog, and
of the requirements and conditions for keeping the dog, as set forth herein.
The notice shall inform the dog owner that he or she may request, in writing, a
hearing to contest the finding and designation within five (5) business days
after delivery of the dangerous dog designation notice, by filing the request
with the animal control officer. Upon receipt of a request for a hearing, the
animal control officer shall promptly notify and deliver the request to the
Hearing Officer designated in subsection (D)2 of this section.
      2.   Within five (5) business days after finding a dog not dangerous, the
officer shall notify the complainant of this finding. The notice shall inform
the complainant that he or she may request, in writing, a hearing to contest
the finding, by filing said request with the animal control officer no later
than five (5) days after receiving the notice. Upon receipt of a request for a
hearing, the animal control officer shall promptly notify and deliver the
request to the Hearing Officer designated in subsection (D)2 of this section.
   (D)   1. Upon a request for a hearing being filed as set forth in subsection
(C) of this section, a hearing shall be held in an expeditious manner, no later
than fifteen (15) days after the date the request for the hearing was received
by the animal control officer.
      2.   The hearing shall be held before a Hearing Officer appointed by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of the City Council. The Hearing Officer
shall not be an employee of the City of Aledo or of the entity which employs
the animal control officer.
      3.   The Hearing Officer shall provide notice of the date, time and
location of the hearing to the dog owner and to the complainant by regular
mail. At the hearing, all interested persons shall be given the opportunity to
present evidence on the issue of the dog's dangerousness. Criteria to be
considered in a hearing required by this section shall include, but not be
limited to, the following:
         (a)   Provocation;
         (b)   Severity of attack or injury to a person or domestic animal;
         (c)   Previous aggressive history of the dog;
         (d)   Observable behavior of the dog;
         (e)   Site and circumstances of the incident; and
         (f)   Statements from interested parties.
   (E)   A determination at a hearing that the dog is in fact a "dangerous dog"
as defined herein shall subject the dog and its owner to the provisions of this
section. A determination that a dog is a "vicious dog" as defined herein shall
subject the dog and its owner to the provisions of sections
6-2-9-2 and
6-2-9-3 of this chapter.
   (F)   Failure of the dog owner to request a hearing shall result in the dog
being finally declared a dangerous dog and shall subject the dog and its owner
to the provisions of this section.
   (G)   The determination by the Hearing Officer that a dog is dangerous or
not dangerous at the conclusion of a hearing conducted under this chapter shall
be final, subject to the right to appeal the determination to a court of
competent jurisdiction pursuant to Illinois law. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff.
1-1-2016)
   (H)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which
has been found to be a dangerous dog unless the person meets the following
requirements:
      1.   Registration Of Dangerous Dogs: The owner shall register a dangerous
dog within ten (10) days of the dog being declared dangerous. The dog must be
registered with the City Clerk by April 1 of each year thereafter. An annual
registration fee shall be paid to the City pursuant to title 13, "Schedule Of
Fees", of this Code;
      2.   Insurance: The owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the City
Clerk proof that he or she has procured liability insurance or a surety bond in
the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) covering
any damage or injury that may be caused by the dangerous dog. The policy shall
contain a provision requiring that the City be notified immediately by the
agent issuing the policy in the event that the insurance policy is canceled,
terminated or expires. The liability insurance or surety bond shall be obtained
prior to the issuing of a permit to keep a dangerous dog. The dog owner shall
sign a statement attesting that he or she shall maintain and not voluntarily
cancel the liability insurance policy during a twelve (12) month period for
which a permit is sought, unless he or she ceases to own or keep the dog prior
to the expiration date of the permit;
      3.   Permanent Identification: Each dangerous dog shall have an injected
microchip to permanently identify the dog; and
      4.   Transfer Of Ownership: The owner of a dangerous dog shall not
transfer ownership of the animal to any other person without providing the City
Clerk and the animal control officer with the name and address of the new
owner. (Ord. 14/2017, 6-5-2017)
   (I)   No person shall permit any dangerous dog to leave the premises of its
owner when not under control by leash or within an enclosed vehicle.
   (J)   The owner of any dog found to be dangerous shall maintain the animal
in such a manner as to prevent its coming in contact with any person not
residing with the owner.
   (K)   Any dog found to be a dangerous dog by the animal control officer or
Hearing Officer on two (2) separate occasions shall be deemed a vicious dog.
(Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-9-2: VICIOUS DOG:
   (A)   It is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for
any person to keep or maintain any dog in the City which has been found to be a
vicious dog pursuant to this chapter or the Animal Control Act. For purposes of
this section, the term "vicious dog" shall mean a dog that, without
justification, attacks a person and causes serious physical injury or death or
any individual dog that has been found to be a "dangerous dog" upon two (2)
separate occasions.
   (B)   If the existence of a nuisance is established, the owner of the dog or
other animal shall be in violation of this chapter. Furthermore, the court may
enter an order restraining the owner from maintaining the nuisance and may
order that the dog or other animal be humanely dispatched. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-
2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-9-3: PROCEDURE FOR DECLARING A DOG VICIOUS:
   (A)   An animal control officer or any adult person may request under oath
that a dog be classified as vicious by submitting a sworn, written complaint on
a form approved by the animal control officer. Upon receipt of the complaint,
the animal control officer shall notify the owner of the dog that a complaint
has been filed and that an investigation into the allegations as set forth in
the complaint will be conducted. During the investigation:
      1.   The custody of any dog which is the subject of the investigation
shall not be transferred by its owner to any other person; nor shall the place
of maintenance of the dog be changed from its owner's residence during that
time, without the consent of the animal control officer; and
      2.   In addition, the dog may be ordered impounded by the animal control
officer if he or she has reason to believe that during the investigation the
dog will cause an immediate danger to the community if it is not immediately
impounded. The owner may appeal the impoundment order to the chief of police at
any time. The chief of police, or his or her designee, shall give the owner a
hearing within three (3) business days of the filing of the appeal.
   (B)   At the conclusion of an investigation, the animal control officer may:
      1.   Determine that the dog is not vicious and, if the dog is impounded,
waive any impoundment fees incurred and release the dog to its owner.
      2.   Determine that the dog is vicious and cause the dog to be humanely
destroyed.
      3.   Determine that the dog is dangerous, in which case the provisions of
section
6-2-9-1 of this chapter shall apply.
   (C)   1. Within five (5) business days after declaring a dog vicious, the
animal control officer shall notify the owner and the complainant of the dog's
designation as a vicious dog. The notice shall inform the dog owner that he or
she may request, in writing, a hearing to contest the finding and designation
within five (5) business days after delivery of the vicious dog designation
notice, by filing the request with the animal control officer no later than
five (5) days after receiving the notice. Upon receipt of a request for a
hearing, the animal control officer shall promptly notify and deliver the
request to the hearing officer designated in subsection (D)2 of this section.
      2.   Within five (5) business days after finding a dog not vicious, the
animal control officer shall notify the complainant and the owner of this
finding. The notice shall inform the complainant that he or she may request, in
writing, a hearing to contest the finding, by filing said request with the
animal control officer no later than five (5) days after receiving the notice.
Upon receipt of a request for a hearing, the animal control officer shall
promptly notify and deliver the request to the hearing officer designated in
subsection (D)2 of this section.
   (D)   1. Upon a request for a hearing being filed as set forth in subsection
(C) of this section, a hearing shall be held in an expeditious manner, no later
than fifteen (15) days after the date the request for the hearing was received
by the animal control officer.
      2.   The hearing shall be held before a hearing officer appointed by the
mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. The hearing officer
shall not be an employee of the city nor of the entity which employs the animal
control officer.
      3.   The hearing officer shall provide notice of the date, time and
location of the hearing to the dog owner and to the complainant by regular
mail. At the hearing, all interested persons shall be given the opportunity to
present evidence on the issue of the dog's viciousness. Criteria to be
considered in a hearing required by this section shall include, but not be
limited to, the following:
         (a)   Provocation;
         (b)   Severity of attack or injury to a person or domestic animal;
         (c)   Previous aggressive history of the dog;
         (d)   Observable behavior of the dog;
         (e)   Site and circumstances of the incident; and
         (f)   Statements from interested parties.
   (E)   The determination by the hearing officer that a dog is vicious or not
vicious at the conclusion of a hearing conducted under this chapter shall be
final, subject to the right to appeal the determination to a court of competent
jurisdiction pursuant to Illinois law. A determination by the hearing officer
that the dog is vicious shall include an order that the dog be humanely
destroyed, in which case the animal control officer shall cause the dog to be
humanely destroyed.
   (F)   If no hearing is requested pursuant to subsection (C)1 of this
section, the dog shall be humanely destroyed.
   (G)   The dog owner shall be responsible for payment of all boarding costs
and other fees as may be required for the city to humanely and safely keep the
animal during any legal proceeding. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-10: IMPOUNDMENT:
6-2-10-1: REDEMPTION OF ANIMAL BY OWNER:
   (A)   In order to redeem a dog, cat or other animal which has been
impounded, the owner shall pay to the animal control officer the current
minimum fee established by Mercer County animal control.
   (B)   In addition to the redemption fee, the owner shall pay to the animal
control officer the minimum current boarding fee established by Mercer County
animal control for the board of the animal for each day or fraction of a day
for which it has been impounded.
   (C)   In the event any impounded animal does not have a current rabies tag,
the owner redeeming the dog or cat shall pay, in addition to the above charges,
the minimum fee established by Mercer County animal control to be applied
toward rabies inoculation for the current year. The inoculation shall be given
within forty eight (48) hours of redemption.
   (D)   In addition to the above mentioned fees, the owner of an impounded
animal will be subject to the other penalties of this chapter. (Ord. 8/2015,
10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11: PROHIBITED ACTIONS; CARE OF ANIMALS:
6-2-11-1: ANIMALS AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
   (A)   Dogs:
      1.   (a) It is unlawful for any dog to run at large within the corporate
limits of the city. If a dog does run at large, the owner or keeper of the dog
shall be in violation of this chapter. Any dog which goes upon any public
street, sidewalk, alley or other public place, unless so designated by the city
council as an off leash area, or upon any private property other than that of
the owner of the dog, shall be deemed to be running at large unless the dog is
firmly held on a leash under the complete control of a physically and mentally
competent person, or is in an enclosed vehicle.
         (b)   In addition, any dog found to be on the property of its owner
shall be deemed to be running at large, unless:
            (1)   It is then and there accompanied by and under the charge of a
physically and mentally competent person; or
            (2)   It is securely restrained by a leash, tether, fence or other
enclosure, or it is in the rear yard of its owner or keeper and is under the
direct control of a person physically capable of restraining the dog; or
            (3)   An electronic pet containment system is then and there in
place which effectively restrains the dog from leaving the property of its
owner.
      2.   Any dog found running at large upon a public street, sidewalk, alley
or other public place or upon any private property other than that of the owner
of the dog shall be impounded by the animal control officer; provided, however,
any vicious dog, which has bitten a human being and cannot be safely captured,
may be slain by the animal control officer or by a police officer.
   (B)   Cats: It is unlawful for any cat to run at large upon a public street,
sidewalk, alley or other public place or upon any private property other than
that of the owner of it and create a nuisance or disturbance. If a cat does run
at large and create a nuisance or disturbance, the owner or keeper of the cat
shall be in violation of this chapter. In addition, the cat may be impounded;
provided, however, any vicious cat, which has bitten a human being and cannot
be safely captured, may be slain by the animal control officer or by a police
officer.
   (C)   Livestock And Fowl: No person shall permit any cattle, horses, swine,
sheep, goats or fowl to run at large within the corporate limits of the city.
No person shall picket or tie any animal in any of the streets of the city for
the purpose of grazing or feeding. Any animal running at large or improperly
tied shall be impounded by the animal control officer; provided, however, any
vicious animal which has bitten a human being and cannot be safely captured may
be slain by the animal control officer or a police officer. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-
19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11-2: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
   (A)   Cruelty To And Endangering Of Animals: No person shall beat, cruelly
ill treat, torment or abuse any animal. No person shall throw or deposit any
poisonous substance on any exposed or private place where it may endanger any
animal. No person shall provoke any animal to bark or bite by taunting it. It
shall be a violation of this chapter for any person convicted of a violation of
this section, or any similar provision of Illinois law, to own, keep, harbor or
act as custodian for any dog or other animal for a period of five (5) years
from the date of said conviction.
   (B)   Abandonment: It shall be unlawful for any animal owner to abandon an
animal where it may become a public charge or may suffer injury or exposure or
allow it to remain within a property in which there is no current resident or
on site proprietor.
   (C)   Impoundment Procedure: The animal control officer is hereby authorized
to remove from any premises and impound any animal or fowl on which cruel
treatment is being inflicted as listed in this section. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-
2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11-3: NUISANCE FEEDING PROHIBITED:
No person shall feed, bait, or allow access to food to any wild, feral, or
stray animal or rodent. No person shall leave or store any food, refuse, or
other material or substance in a manner that creates an attractant for any
wild, feral, or stray animals or rodents. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-
2016)
6-2-11-4: POLICE DOGS:
   (A)   Teasing, Striking Or Tampering With Police Dogs Prohibited: No person
shall wilfully or maliciously taunt, torment, tease, beat, strike, or
administer or subject any desensitizing drugs, chemicals or substance to any
dog used by a police officer in the performance of his or her functions or
duties, or when placed in confinement off duty; and no person shall interfere
or meddle with any such dog used by the police department or any other law
enforcement agency or any handler thereof in the performance of the functions
or duties of the police department or other law enforcement agency.
   (B)   Injuring Or Killing Police Dogs Prohibited: No person shall wilfully
or maliciously torture, torment, mutilate, injure, disable, poison, or kill any
dog used by the police department or any other law enforcement agency in the
performance of the functions or duties of the police department or other law
enforcement agency or when placed in confinement off duty. However, the animal
control officer, police officer or veterinarian may perform euthanasia in
emergency situations when delay would cause the animal undue pain and
suffering. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11-5: TRAPPING ANIMALS; EXCEPTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to trap animals within the city limits. For
purposes of this section, "trap" means to capture or attempt to capture, by
setting or placing a leg hold trap, body gripping trap, cage or live trap, or
similar device to capture, hold, or kill animals. This section shall not apply,
however, to any law enforcement officers acting in the course of their duties
or to any person who, prior to setting traps, obtains permission to trap within
the city limits from the police department and the state of Illinois. (Ord. 8/
2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11-6: BURNING OF ANIMAL MATTER PROHIBITED:
No person shall burn any feathers, hides or any other animal matter within the
corporate limits of the city. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11-7: DISPOSAL OF DEAD ANIMALS:
   (A)   Prohibited Disposal: No person shall deposit, place or throw any dead
animal or fatally sick or injured animal, or part thereof on any public or
private place, or into any reservoir, sewer or well, or on the banks of any
stream, lake, pond or other body of water.
   (B)   Burial: All dead animals, or parts thereof, may be buried at a
distance of not less than one hundred feet (100') of any residence or well; and
the carcass shall be placed underground and well covered with dirt at least
four feet (4') underground to the upper part of the carcass.
   (C)   Immediate Disposal: No person shall fail to immediately dispose of any
dead animal found upon the property under his or her possession or control.
(Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-11-8: DOGS PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC AREAS ON CERTAIN DAYS:
No person shall permit or allow any dog owned by him or her, or under his or
her maintenance and control, to be present at any public event involving large
numbers of people, including, but not limited to, Aledo Rhubarb Festival and
Aledo Antique Days, and any other day when, in the discretion of the Chief of
Police, the presence of dogs at such an event constitutes a danger or threat to
the safety of the public, and the Chief of Police has caused signs to be posted
at the event informing the public that dogs are not permitted. This section
shall not apply to dogs trained to assist physically impaired individuals, nor
to certified police dogs. (Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-2-12: DOG PARK REGULATIONS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to utilize the Aledo Bark Park in
a manner which violates the following rules:
      1.   Hours. The dog park is open daily from dawn until dusk unless closed
for maintenance or weather.
      2.   Dogs Only. The dog park is for use of dogs and handlers only. No
other animals are permitted in the dog park.
      3.   Leashes. Dogs must be on a leash when outside the designated off-
leash areas.
      4.   Regulations.
         (a)   Dogs must be in view and under control of their handler at all
times.
         (b)   All handlers must be 16 years of age.
         (c)   Children under the age of 13 must be supervised by an adult.
         (d)   Handlers are required to pick up and dispose of their dog’s
waste.
         (e)   No more than two dogs per handler.
         (f)   Handlers must stop their dog from digging and must fill any
holes their dog creates.
         (g)   Dogs displaying aggressive behavior are not permitted in the dog
park.
         (h)   All dogs must have a valid rabies vaccination tag.
      5.   Prohibited Items. The following items are prohibited at the dog
park:
         (a)   Bicycles, skates, or rollerblades.
         (b)   Strollers and baby carriages.
         (c)   Dog treats and rawhides.
         (d)   Food (dog or human).
      6.   Prohibited Activities. The following activities are prohibited at
the dog park:
         (a)   Smoking and use of any tobacco products or their like.
         (b)   Sports activities.
         (c)   Dog training classes.
         (d)   Business uses.
      7.   Prohibited Dogs. The following dogs are prohibited at the dog park:
         (a)   Dogs under five (5) months of age.
         (b)   Female dogs in heat.
   (B)   Any person entering the dog park acknowledges the risks and possible
dangers associated with dog parks and assumes the risk of injury to themselves
and their dogs.
(Ord. 09/2025, 4-7-2025)
6-2-13: PENALTY:
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined pursuant
to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this Code.
(Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
CHAPTER 3
DOGS AND OTHER ANIMALS 1
(Rep. by Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)

6-4-1: ADMISSION FEES, FRAUDULENTLY AVOIDING PAYMENT OF:
It shall be unlawful for any person fraudulently to enter, without payment of
the proper admission fee, any theater, ballroom, lecture, concert or other
place where admission fees are charged; provided, however, that nothing herein
contained shall be deemed to prohibit or restrict the free admission of police
officers engaged in the performance of police duties to any place of public
entertainment or amusement. (1969 Code)
6-4-2: ASSAULT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit "assault" which is hereby defined
as any conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a
battery. (1969 Code)
6-4-3: BATTERY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit battery. A person commits battery
if he intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any means
causes bodily harm to an individual or makes physical contact of an insulting
or provoking nature with an individual. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-
2017)
6-4-4: CIGARETTES OR TOBACCO, SALE TO OR POSSESSION BY MINORS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to buy for or sell, furnish or
give away, to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age, either directly or
indirectly, any cigar, cigarette, tobacco, compound of tobacco used in filling
up or making up of a cigarette, cigarette papers, tobacco product, nicotine
product, alternative nicotine product, electronic cigarette or other product,
device, or implement designed for use in inhaling or ingesting nicotine or
alternative nicotine products.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age
to buy or otherwise possess any cigar, cigarette, tobacco, compound of tobacco
used in filling up or making up of a cigarette, cigarette papers, tobacco
product, nicotine product, alternative nicotine product, electronic cigarette
or other product, device, or implement designed for use in inhaling or
ingesting nicotine or alternative nicotine products. (Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017;
Ord. 47/2019, 12-16- 2019)

6-4-4.2: SMOKING PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PLACES AND PLACES OF EMPLOYMENT:
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to smoke in a public place or a place of
employment within the City of Aledo.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to smoke within fifteen feet (15') of
the entrance of any public place or place of employment within the city.
   (C)   It is unlawful for any person to smoke in any vehicle owned, leased,
or operated by the city.
   (D)   It is unlawful for the owner, employer, occupant or lessee in control
of a public place to knowingly permit smoking in any enclosed area in a public
place or place of employment that is not specifically exempted as described in
section
6-4-4.2 of this chapter. (Ord. 47/2019, 12-16-2019)
6-4-4.3: EXEMPTIONS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary, smoking is
allowed in the following areas:
   (A)   Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a
childcare, adult daycare, or healthcare facility or any other home-based
business open to the public.
   (B)   Any public place or place of employment that is a tobacco dealer,
whose principal business is the sale at retail of tobacco and tobacco related
products; provided that smoke generated by smoking on the premises of the
tobacco dealer does not infiltrate into enclosed areas where smoking is
otherwise prohibited; and no food or liquor license has been granted.
   (C)   Private and semiprivate rooms in nursing homes and long term care
facilities that are occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers
and have requested in writing to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking
is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the nursing
home.
   (D)   Hotel and motel rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as
smoking rooms provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor must be
contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into nonsmoking rooms
or other areas where smoking is prohibited. No more than twenty five percent
(25%) of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as
rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking
may not be changed, except to permanently add additional nonsmoking rooms.
   (E)   Private vehicles, not including public transportation facilities or
government vehicles. (Ord. 47/2019, 12-16-2019)
6-4-5: CONCEALING KNOWLEDGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal knowledge of the commission of
any offense or to conceal knowledge of any unlawful act as defined in this
Code. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-6: DAMAGE TO CITY PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, deliberately or maliciously
damage, deface, or in any way render inoperative, any property owned or under
the control and operation of the City. The word "property" as used hereinabove
means both real and personal property, including any locks, fences, gates,
chains, padlocks or other devices or fixtures whatsoever that may be installed
upon or used in connection with property owned or operated by the City. (Ord.
4/65, 10-18-1965; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-7: DELINQUENCY, ENCOURAGING:
It shall be unlawful for any person, by any act or neglect, to encourage, aid
or cause a child to come within the purview of the juvenile authorities; and it
shall likewise be unlawful for any person, after notice that a driver's license
of any child has been suspended or revoked, to permit such child to operate a
motor vehicle during the period that such driver's license is suspended. (1969
Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-8: DISORDERLY CONDUCT; BREACH OF PEACE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in disorderly conduct within the
City. A person commits disorderly conduct when he or she:
   (A)   Acts in a violent, tumultuous, or offensive manner so as to alarm or
disturb another, or to provoke a breach of the peace;
   (B)   Threatens, traduces, quarrels, fights or challenges to fight another;
   (C)   Uses obscene, offensive, profane or unseemly language to the
annoyance, disturbance or vexation of another;
   (D)   Transmits or causes to be transmitted, in any manner, to any peace
officer, public officer or public employee, a report to the effect that an
offense will be committed, is being committed, or has been committed, knowing
at the time of the transmission that there is no reasonable ground for
believing that the offense will be committed, is being committed, or has been
committed;
   (E)   Calls the number "911" for the purpose of making or transmitting a
false alarm or complaint and reporting information when, at the time the call
or transmission is made, the person knows there is no reasonable ground for
making the call or transmission and further knows that the call or transmission
could result in the emergency response of any public safety agency; or makes
repeated unnecessary calls to the number "911" when no emergency exists;
   (F)   Transmits or causes to be transmitted in any manner to the Police
Department or Fire Department of the City, or any privately owned and operated
ambulance service, a false request for an ambulance, emergency medical
technician-ambulance or emergency medical technician-paramedic knowing at the
time there is no reasonable ground for believing that the assistance is
required; and
   (G)   Enters upon the property of another, for a lewd or unlawful purpose or
to look into the dwelling through any window or other opening. (Ord. 22/2017,
6-19-2017)
6-4-9: DRUNKENNESS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be found drunk, intoxicated or under the
influence of intoxicating liquor upon any public thoroughfare or other public
place. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-10: FALSE PRETENSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain any food, drink, goods, wares or
merchandise under false pretenses, or to enter any public place and call for
refreshments or other articles and receive and refuse to pay for same, or
depart without paying for or satisfying the person from whom he received the
food, goods, wares and merchandise. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-11: GENERAL OFFENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act or fail to perform any
requirement which is prohibited or required by State law, insofar as such laws
are applicable to Municipal government. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-
2017)
6-4-12: INDECENT EXPOSURE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any of the following acts in any
public place within the City:
   (A)   Engage in sexual penetration or other sexual conduct;
   (B)   Appear in a state of nudity or make any indecent, lewd or lascivious
exposure of body parts;
   (C)   Engage in any other indecent, lewd or lascivious act or behavior.
Indecent exposure does not include the act of breast feeding of an infant.
"Public place" for the purpose of this section means any place where such act
or conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. (Ord. 22/2017, 6-
19-2017)
6-4-13: INJURIOUS MATERIAL ON THOROUGHFARES, DEPOSITS OF:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, place or allow to remain in or
upon any public thoroughfare any material or substance injurious to person or
property. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-14: JUNK, KEEPING OF RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to store or keep any old articles or
materials which may be classified as junk adjacent to or in close proximity to
any schoolhouse, church, public parks, public grounds, business buildings or
residences without first providing proper and tight buildings for the storage
of the same. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-15: OBSCENE CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate in any place open to
the public view within the City. (Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-16: POSTING BILLS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, post, paint, print or nail any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind on any curbstone,
flagstone or any other portion or part of any sidewalk, or upon any tree,
lamppost, hitchpost, telegraph pole, hydrant or upon any private wall, door or
gate, without the consent in writing of the owner of the wall, door or gate;
provided, however, that this section shall not prevent posting by proper City
and County officials of election signs, polling place signs and other signs or
placards necessary under the law to the conduct of elections. (1969 Code; amd.
Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-17: PROPERTY, MALICIOUS INJURY TO:
It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully and maliciously to injure, deface,
mutilate, remove, pull down, break or in any manner interfere with or molest or
secrete or destroy any real or personal property belonging to or under the
control of any person or of the City. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-18: RESISTING AN OFFICER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere wilfully with, resist, delay,
obstruct, molest or threaten to molest any officer of the City in the exercise
of his official duties. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-19: TRESPASSING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass within the City upon
either public or private property. A person commits trespass when he or she:
   (A)   Knowingly and without legal authority enters or remains within or on
any building;
   (B)   Enters upon any property or into any building in violation of a notice
posted or exhibited at any point of approach on the property;
   (C)   Enters upon any property or into any building when he or she has been
given prior written or verbal notice, by any owner or occupant thereof, that
such entry is prohibited;
   (D)   Remains in or on any building or property after being told, by any
owner or occupant thereof, to leave the building or property; or
   (E)   Enters a park after normal closing hours without having received
permission from the person with legal authority over the park. (Ord. 22/2017,
6-19-2017)
6-4-20: WATER FLOWING UPON STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any water to flow into or upon any
public thoroughfare. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-21: WINDOWSILLS TO BE KEPT CLEAR:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or keep on any windowsill, porch
or other projection above the first story of any building abutting on any
sidewalk any article which might do injury by falling upon any person on the
sidewalk in front of such building, unless such article be securely fastened or
protected by screens. (1969 Code; amd. Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-22: LIQUOR CONSUMPTION OR POSSESSION ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
The consumption or the transportation and/or possession of alcoholic liquor by
any person while on public property including, but not limited to, all public
parks located within the City, is hereby forbidden except when the
transportation and/or possession of alcoholic liquor is in the original package
with the seal unbroken; provided, however, that no person shall be guilty of a
violation of this section if at the time he is in possession or the
transportation of alcoholic liquor he is located on public property operating
under a valid special events liquor license as provided under section
3-2-19  of this Code, or during a public event in locations as designated by
the Chief of Police or City Administrator.
Every person who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be subject
to a fine pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this Code. (Ord. 22/
2017, 6-19-2017; amd. Ord. 4/2023. 2-6-2023)
6-4-23: THROWING OBJECTS FROM VEHICLES PROHIBITED IN PARADES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, hand or deliver, or
cause to have thrown, handed or delivered any candy, treats, or any tangible
articles from any vehicle participating in any parade. Vehicles participating
in any parade shall include any and all vehicles located either along the
parade route or at the beginning or ending of any such route regardless of
whether any such vehicles are moving or stationary.
   (B)   Any person who violates subsection (A) of this section shall be fined
pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this Code. (Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-
2017)
6-4-24: LITTER PROHIBITED:
   (A)   Declared Nuisance: All litter which has been stored, dumped or
accumulated upon any real property improved or vacant, and any used motor
vehicle parts or similar scrap metal stored or allowed to exist in the open on
any property, unless necessary for the operation of a business enterprise
lawfully conducted thereon, is hereby declared to constitute a nuisance.
   (B)   Prohibition: No person shall throw, deposit or dump litter, used motor
vehicle parts or similar scrap metal on any property except in an approved
container or in a public landfill. (Ord. 08/2012, 6-4-2012; amd. Ord. 22/2017,
6-19-2017)
   (C)   Definitions:
      GARBAGE: All accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, including
grass, vegetation and noxious weeds and any other matter of any nature
whatsoever that is subject to decay, putrefaction, and the generation of
noxious and offensive smells or odors, of which, during and after decay, may be
a food source for rodents and may serve as breeding or feeding materials for
flies and/or other germ carrying insects; bottles, cans, or other food
containers which due to their ability to retain water can serve as a breeding
place for mosquitoes, or other water breeding insects. It includes rejected
household food waste, offal, pet feces, swill and carrion.
      LITTER: Includes but is not limited to garbage and any other worthless,
unwanted material, items, debris, cigarette butts, cans, bottles, chewing gum,
candy, food scraps or other scraps that is rejected, discarded or thrown out.
(Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
6-4-25: POSSESSION AND CONSUMPTION OF CANNABIS:
   (A)   For the purpose of this Section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
 
ACT:                     The Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act
                         (410 ILCS 130/1 et seq.).
                         Includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which
                         are identified as including any parts of the plant
                         Cannabis Sativa, whether growing or not, the seeds
                         thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such
                         plant and any compound, manufacture, sale, derivative,
                         mixture, or preparation of such plant, its seeds or
                         resin including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all
                         other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally
                         occurring or synthetically produced ingredients,
                         whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction,
CANNABIS:                or independently by means of chemical synthesis; but
                         shall not include the mature stalks of such plant,
                         fiber produced from stalks, oil or cake made from the
                         seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture,
                         salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such
                         mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom),
                         fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of such
                         plant which is incapable of germination. "Cannabis"
                         does not include industrial hemp as defined and
                         authorized under the Illinois Industrial Hemp Act (505
                         ILCS 89/5).
                         Includes equipment, products, or materials intended to
                         be used for planting, propagating, cultivating,
                         growing, harvesting, manufacturing, producing,
CANNABIS PARAPHERNALI A: processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging,
                         repackaging storing, containing, concealing,
                         ingesting, or otherwise introducing cannabis into the
                         human body.
CRTA:                    The Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS 705/1 et
                         seq.).
                         Any place where a person could reasonably be expected
                         to be observed by others. "Public place" includes all
                         parts of buildings owned in whole or in part, or
                         leased, by the State of Illinois, the City of Aledo,
                         or any other unit of local government. "Public place"
                         also includes all areas in a park, recreation area,
PUBLIC PLACE:            wildlife area or playground owned in whole or in part,
                         leased, or managed by the State, the City of Aledo, or
                         any other unit of local government. "Public place"
                         does not include a private residence unless the
                         private residence is used to provide licensed child
                         care, foster care, or other similar social service
                         care on the premises.
 
   (B)   In General: It is unlawful for any person who is twenty-one (21) years
of age or older to possess cannabis in excess of the following limits:
      1.   For residents of the State of Illinois:
         a.   Thirty (30) grams of cannabis flower;
         b.   Five hundred (500) milligrams of THC contained in a cannabis-
infused product;
         c.   Five (5) grams of cannabis concentrate.
      2.   For individuals who are not residents of the State of Illinois:
         a.   Fifteen (15) grams of cannabis flower;
         b.   Two hundred fifty (250) milligrams of THC contained in a
cannabis-infused product;
         c.   Two and one half (2.5) grams of cannabis concentrate.
   (C)   Minors:
      1.   Possession: It is unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-
one (21) to possess or consume cannabis.
      2.   Sales To Minors: No cannabis business, or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent, or employee thereof shall sell, give, or deliver
cannabis to any person under the age of twenty-one (21). No person, after
purchasing or otherwise obtaining cannabis shall sell, give, or deliver such
cannabis to any person under the age of twenty-one (21).
      3.   Furnishing Or Using False Or Fraudulent ID: Any person under the age
of twenty-one (21) who presents or offers to any cannabis business, or any
officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee thereof, any
evidence of age and identity which is false, fraudulent, modified, or not their
own for the purpose of ordering, purchasing, procuring, or attempting to order,
purchase, or procure cannabis, or who has in their possession any false,
fraudulent, or modified evidence of age or identity is guilty of a violation of
this Section 6-2-5-3.
   (D)   Medical Use Of Cannabis: Notwithstanding anything in this Section to
the contrary, it shall not be unlawful for any individual who is a registered
qualifying patient or a registered designated caregiver, as those terms are
defined in the Act, to engage in the medical use of cannabis, or to possess
cannabis for the purpose of engaging or assisting in the medical use of
cannabis in accordance with the provisions of the Act. An individual is
presumed to be acting lawfully and in compliance with this Section and the
terms of the Act where such individual is in possession of (i) a valid registry
identification card issued pursuant to the Act, and (ii) no more than two and
one half (2.5) ounces of cannabis (or such other amount as authorized by the
Act or the CRTA).
   (E)   Cultivation Of Cannabis: It shall be unlawful for any individual to
cultivate cannabis for personal use; provided, however, that a registered
qualifying patient under the Act may cultivate up to five (5) cannabis plants,
with a cumulative limit of five (5) plants per household.
   (F)   Possession And Use Prohibited: Notwithstanding the foregoing, it shall
be unlawful for any person to engage in any of the following:
      1.   Possession or use of cannabis on a school bus, unless permitted for
a qualifying patient or caregiver pursuant to the Act;
      2.   Possession or use of cannabis on the grounds of any preschool,
primary school, or secondary school, unless permitted for a qualifying patient
or caregiver pursuant to the Act;
      3.   Possession or use of cannabis in any correctional facility;
      4.   Possession of cannabis in a vehicle, unless the cannabis is in a
reasonably secured, sealed container and reasonably inaccessible while the
vehicle is moving;
      5.   Use of cannabis in a motor vehicle;
      6.   Possession or use of cannabis in a private residence that is used at
any time to provide licensed child care or similar social service care on the
premises;
      7.   Use of cannabis in any public place within the City, including any
public area as defined in Section 6-11-1 of this Code;
      8.   Use of cannabis knowingly in close physical proximity to anyone
under twenty-one (21) years of age who is not a registered medical cannabis
patient under the Act;
      9.   Smoking cannabis in any place where smoking is prohibited under the
Smoke Free Illinois Act (410 ILCS 82/1 et seq.);
      10.   Operating, navigating, or being in actual physical control of any
motor vehicle, aircraft, or motorboat while using or under the influence of
cannabis in violation of Section 11-501 or 11-502.1 of the Illinois Vehicle
Code;
      11.   Facilitating the use of cannabis by any person who is not allowed
to use cannabis under this Section;
      12.   Transferring cannabis to any person contrary to this Section, the
Act or the CRTA;
      13.   The use of cannabis by a person who has a school bus permit or a
commercial driver's license while on duty.
   (G)   Penalty: Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this
Section shall be subject to a fine of not less than three hundred dollars
($300.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 49/
2019, 12-16-2019)
CHAPTER 5
NUISANCES
SECTION:
6-5-1:   Offensive, Obnoxious Premises
6-5-2:   Saloons; Disorderly Houses
6-5-3:   Dead Animals 1  (Rep. by Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
6-5-4:   Watercourse Obstructions
6-5-5:   Dilapidated Buildings
6-5-6:   Notice To Abate
6-5-7:   Process Of Action
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  6-2-11-7 of this title.
6-5-1: OFFENSIVE, OBNOXIOUS PREMISES:
Any pen, pigsty, stable, shed or other place, on or upon which any horse, cow,
hog or other animal, or animals, have been, are or may be kept or confined; or
any cellar, vault, privy, sewer, or other place; the leaving of any dead animal
in or upon any street or other place unburied; or the obstructing of any street
or other public ground; or the obstructing or fouling any watercourse within
the corporate limits of the city; or the keeping of any slaughterhouse, soap
factory or rendery, either within said corporate limits or within one and one-
half (11/2) miles thereof, in such manner or condition as to become filthy,
offensive, or an annoyance to any person or neighborhood, or to the public
generally, are each hereby severally defined and declared to be nuisances, and
the owner or keeper thereof, or person permitting any of the aforesaid
nuisances to exist or continue, shall be deemed to be the author of a nuisance
and shall be subject to the provisions and penalties as in this code provided.
(Ord. 13/00, 4-19-1901)
6-5-2: SALOONS; DISORDERLY HOUSES:
Any person who shall own, occupy, keep or maintain any saloon, beer garden or
gallon shop; or any house of prostitution, or assignation; or any bawdy or
disorderly house; or any gaming or gambling place, or any business place or
establishment within the city or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the
corporate limits of said city, in such manner as to be offensive or unwholesome
to the neighborhood in which it is located or any family residing therein,
shall be deemed to be guilty of maintaining a nuisance. (Ord. 13/00, 4-19-1901)
6-5-3: DEAD ANIMALS 1 :
(Rep. by Ord. 8/2015, 10-19-2015, eff. 1-1-2016)
 
Notes
1 2. See section
  6-2-11-7 of this title.
6-5-4: WATERCOURSE OBSTRUCTIONS:
Any person who shall erect or maintain, or cause the same to be done, any
obstruction to any watercourse, ravine or slough within the limits of the city,
so as to interrupt or interfere with the running of water in the same, or shall
cause to be placed in any watercourse, ravine or slough, any substance which
will stop or interfere with the flow of water therein, or place or cause to be
placed in any watercourse any dead animal, garbage, or other filthy or unclean
thing, shall be deemed the author of a nuisance. (Ord. 13/00, 4-19-1901)
6-5-5: DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS:
Any person or persons who shall suffer or permit any old building, or other
structure, on or upon any premises belonging to or occupied by him, to become
dilapidated, or in such condition that it will be liable to fall down; or in
such condition that it is dangerous on account of fire or storms, shall be
deemed the author of a nuisance. (Ord. 4/02, 7-7-1902)
6-5-6: NOTICE TO ABATE:
In all cases when the provisions of this chapter, or any section thereof, shall
have been violated and notice to the person so offending shall have been given
to remove or abate the same and such person shall fail or neglect or refuse so
to do within the time required by such notice, when notice is required to be
given, or shall fail to do as required by this chapter or any section thereof,
it shall be the duty of the chief of police at once to proceed to remove or
abate the same and all reasonable charges and expenses incurred by the chief of
police in the performance of such duty may be recovered from the offender in a
separate action, or may be included in the judgment for the fine or penalty
incurred by reason of the violation of this chapter, or the particular section
so violated. (Ord. 13/00, 4-19-1901)
6-5-7: PROCESS OF ACTION:
In all actions for violations of any of the provisions of this chapter, or any
section thereof, the first process shall be a summons; provided, however, that
a warrant for the arrest of the offender may issue, in the first instance, upon
the affidavit of any competent person that the chapter has been violated, and
that the person making the complaint, has reasonable grounds to believe that
the party charged is guilty thereof; and any person arrested upon such warrant
shall, without unnecessary delay be taken before a proper court, or before the
clerk of the circuit court, to be tried for the alleged offense. (Ord. 13/00,
4-19-1901)
CHAPTER 6
RAILROADS
(Rep. by Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
CHAPTER 7
TOY VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-7-1:   Definitions
6-7-2:   Restricted Areas
6-7-3:   Outside Restricted Areas
6-7-4:   Parental Responsibility
6-7-5:   Signs Posted
6-7-6:   Penalty
6-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "pushcart" when used in this chapter shall also include a scooter or
any other device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride. (Ord.
6/01, 7-16-2001)
6-7-2: RESTRICTED AREAS:
   (A)   Business District: No person shall operate or use an electric battery
powered scooter, skateboard, pushcart, rollerblades, or roller skates within
the city's "business district" as defined below during any calendar day. For
the purposes of this section, the "business district" is defined as follows:
A rectangular area within the city of Aledo, the perimeter of which is located
where the following streets and avenues intersect with the other: The northern
boundary line is N.W. 2nd Street and N.E. 2nd Street; the eastern boundary line
is N.E. 3rd Avenue and S.E. 3rd Avenue; the southern boundary line is S.E. 3rd
Street and S.W. 3rd Street; and the western boundary line is S.W. 3rd Avenue
and N.W. 3rd Avenue, the District to include any sidewalk and/or parking area
lying on the other side of the outside right-of-way line for any of the streets
and avenues named above.
   (B)   Central Park Pavilion: No person shall operate or use an electric
battery powered scooter, skateboard, pushcart, rollerblades, or roller skates
in the Central park pavilion located in the city of Aledo, Illinois. (Ord. 8/
2003, 11-3-2003)
6-7-3: OUTSIDE RESTRICTED AREAS:
In all areas outside the "business district" of the city of Aledo as defined in
section
6-7-2 of this chapter, no person shall use or operate an electric battery
powered scooter, skateboard, pushcart, rollerblades, or roller skates
(collectively referred to as "toy vehicles") in the city of Aledo, Mercer
County, Illinois, in violation of any of the following regulations:
   (A)   Each person using or operating any toy vehicle on a roadway shall obey
all traffic signals and signs unless otherwise directed by a police officer;
   (B)   No person using or operating any toy vehicle on a roadway shall use or
operate such toy vehicle in a reckless manner so as to pose a danger of harm or
injury to another individual, including the operator thereof, or pose a
potential likelihood of accidental death or injury to anyone, including the
operator, from a collision with a vehicle lawfully operated upon the city's
roadway;
   (C)   Every person using or operating any toy vehicle on a roadway shall
ride as near as possible to the right hand side of the roadway and shall
exercise due care when passing a standing or parked vehicle;
   (D)   Any person using or operating a toy vehicle on a roadway shall yield
the right of way to any motor vehicle thereon and to any pedestrian located in
any crosswalk on any street in the city; and
   (E)   No person using or operating a toy vehicle on a roadway shall attach
himself to any moving motor vehicle. (Ord. 08/2003, 11-3-2003)
6-7-4: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or
knowingly permit any child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 6/01, 7-16-2001)
6-7-5: SIGNS POSTED:
The chief of police shall erect appropriate signs designating the city's
"business district" as defined in section
6-7-2 of this chapter as a no battery powered scooters, skateboard/pushcart,
rollerblades or roller skates area. Such signs giving reasonable notice of the
foregoing prohibition shall be posted in conformance with the provisions of 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-207 and 5/11-208(b). (Ord. 8/2003, 11-3-2003)
6-7-6: PENALTY:
It is unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any
act required under any of the provisions of this chapter. Any person who
violates this chapter shall be subject to a fine pursuant to title 12,
"Schedule Of Fines", of this Code. (Ord. 22/2017, 6-19-2017)
CHAPTER 8
ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS
SECTION:
6-8-1:   Abandonment Restrictions
6-8-1: ABANDONMENT RESTRICTIONS:
Whoever abandons or discards in any place accessible to children any
refrigerator, icebox or ice chest of a capacity of one and one-half (11/2)
cubic feet or more, which has attached a lid or door which may be opened or
fastened shut by means of an attached latch, or who, being the owner, lessee or
manager of such place, knowingly permits such abandoned or discarded
refrigerator, icebox or ice chest to remain there in such condition, or whoever
maintains or allows upon his premises, being the owner, lessee or manager of
such premises any well, cistern, cave or other aperture accessible to children
without sufficient covering so that children cannot have access thereto, shall
be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 6/54, 7-19-1954)
CHAPTER 9
WEEDS
SECTION:
6-9-1:   Definitions
6-9-2:   Weeds And Trees Declared A Nuisance
6-9-3:   Grass Exceeding Six Inches In Length Declared A Nuisance
6-9-4:   Length Restriction
6-9-5:   Notice To Remove
6-9-6:   Abatement
6-9-7:   Lien For Unpaid Charges
6-9-8:   Foreclosure Of Lien
6-9-9:   Violations
6-9-10:   Dead Trees
6-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
   Each word below when used in this chapter, including this section, shall
have that definition as given herein:
   ANYONE: Shall include contract seller or purchaser, trustee, partner,
partnership, tenant, land trustee beneficiary, association, or corporation.
   OCCUPANT: Shall include any tenant, lessee, licensee, or anyone having the
right to be in possession of any lot or tract of land in the city that is
privately owned.
   PERSON: See definition of Anyone.
   RENDERED: The date that the statement or notice was deposited in a
receptacle of the United States post office.
   WEEDS: Are not restricted to those named in section
6-9-2 of this chapter, but shall include other common species that will grow in
the city. (Ord. 13/87, 9-21-1987)
6-9-2: WEEDS AND TREES DECLARED A NUISANCE:
   Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cockleburr or other
weeds of like kind, found growing or standing uncut or otherwise uncontrolled
on any lot or tract of land in the city, including any land lying between any
property line thereof running next or nearest to any street or alley and the
closest edge of the concrete, asphalt, or other surface material constituting
the publicly traveled street or alley running in front, along the side, or in
the rear of said lot or tract of land, are hereby declared to be a nuisance.
   Any tree which is so located as to extend its branches over an alley,
street, sidewalk, public way or highway, unless the same shall be kept so
trimmed that there shall be a clear height of not less than 12 feet above
vehicular traffic and not less than nine feet above all sidewalks, unobstructed
by branches is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
   Dead, decaying, or broken branches or stubs of trees which fall or may fall
upon the public ways, sidewalks, or adjacent parcels of private property, or
which are or may become a menace to persons or vehicles upon the public ways,
sidewalks, or adjacent parcels of private property are hereby declared to be a
nuisance.
(Ord. 13/87, 9-21-1987; amd. Ord. 03/2025, 2-18-2025)
6-9-3: GRASS EXCEEDING SIX INCHES IN LENGTH DECLARED A NUISANCE:
Any grass or other cover allowed or permitted to grow to a length in excess of
six inches (6"), excluding any trees, brushes, flowers or other ornamental
plants, on any lot or tract of land in the city, including any land lying
between any property line thereof running next or nearest to any street or
alley and the closest edge of the concrete, asphalt, or other surface material
constituting the publicly traveled street or alley running in front, along the
side, or in the rear of said lot or tract of land, are hereby declared to be a
nuisance to the extent that such grass or other cover exceeds such length.
(Ord. 13/87, 9-21-1987)
6-9-4: LENGTH RESTRICTION:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit or allow any weeds, grass or other
cover, or plants, but excluding trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental
plants properly cultivated, to grow to a length in excess of six inches (6") on
any lot or tract of land in the city either owned or occupied by anyone either
individually or as a trustee, contract seller or purchaser, partner in a
partnership, tenant, land trust beneficiary, or corporation, including any land
lying between any property line thereof running next or nearest to any street
or alley and the closet edge of the concrete, asphalt, or other surface
material constituting the publicly traveled street or alley running in front,
along the side, or in the rear of said lot or tract of land, the owner and the
occupant being each responsible to keep the weeds, grass or other cover, or
plants described above cut and mowed to a length no greater than six inches
(6") on not only the lot(s) or tract of land owned or occupied by him, but also
any strip of land lying within any property line and street surface line as
described above. (Ord. 13/87, 9-21-1987)
6-9-5: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
It shall be the duty of the city clerk upon receipt of notice that a violation
(s) of this chapter has occurred, to serve or cause to be served, a notice upon
the owner or the occupant of any premises on which weeds, trees, grass or other
cover, or plants are permitted or allowed to grow in violation of the
provisions of this chapter and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within
five (5) days after the date notice is sent. Premises shall include any strip
of land between any property line located nearest any street or alley and the
edge of the surface area of any street or alley as defined above.
(Ord. 13/87, 9-21-1987; amd. Ord. 03/2025, 2-18-2025)
6-9-6: ABATEMENT:
If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within five (5) days, then
the Director of Public Works and Utilities may proceed to abate such nuisance
(s), keeping an account of the expense of the abatement, and such expense shall
be charged and paid by such owner or occupant. The fee for abatement shall be
computed pursuant to title 13, “Schedule Of Fees”, of this Code for the
cutting, mowing, trimming, or removal of any and all weeds, grass or other
cover, or plants, all as described above, for each time that abatement of a
nuisance by the City becomes necessary.
(Ord. 14/2017, 6-5-2017; amd. Ord. 03/2025, 2-18-2025)
6-9-7: LIEN FOR UNPAID CHARGES:
Charges for cutting, mowing, trimming, or removing any weeds, trees, grass or
other cover, or plants shall be a lien upon the premises owned or occupied by
any person in any capacity as defined above. Charges shall include any expense
incurred in removing any nuisance existing on any strip of land between any
property line of any lot or tract of land and the edge of any street or alley
running in front, to the side, or in the rear of the lot or tract premises, but
the lien shall apply only against the lot or tract of land in question.
Whenever a bill for such charges remains unpaid for thirty (30) days after it
has been rendered, the City Clerk may file with the Recorder of Deeds for
Mercer County, a statement of the lien claim. This statement shall contain a
legal description of the lot(s) or tract of land in question, the expenses and
the costs incurred, the date the weeds, trees, grass or other cover, or plants
constituting the nuisance were either cut, mowed, trimmed, or removed, and a
notice that the City claims a lien for this amount. Notice of such lien claim
shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address is known, but the
failure of the City Clerk to record such lien claim or to mail such notice, or
the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not affect the right of
the City to foreclose the lien for such charges as provided below nor affect
the right of the City to elect to file an action at law to collect such unpaid
charges by securing a judgment and thereafter pursuing all available collection
remedies against the owner or occupant.
