with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to
facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole,
when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed
in accordance with plans approved by the city. The manhole shall be installed
by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained and operated by him so as
to be safe and accessible at all times.
   (M)   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of
waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special
conditions for discharge established by the city or regulatory agencies having
jurisdiction over the discharge.
   (N)   The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analysis to be performed
by the owner shall be as stipulated by the city, but no less than once per year
the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the
wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal, state and
local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of
measurements and laboratory analysis to the city at such times and in such
manner as prescribed by the city. The owner shall bear the expense of all
measurements, analysis, and reporting required by the city. At such times as
deemed necessary, the city reserves the right to take measurements and samples
for analyses by an outside laboratory service.
   (O)   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of
Water And Wastewater", published by the American Public Health Association, and
shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples
taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been
required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream
manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is
connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to
reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the
existence of hazards of life, limb, and property. The particular analyses
involved will determine whether a twenty four (24) hour composite of all
outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples
should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses
are obtained from a twenty four (24) hour composite of all outfalls, whereas
pHs are determined from periodic grab samples.
   (P)   No statement contained in this section shall be construed as
preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any
industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character
may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the
industrial concern, provided such payments are in accordance with the federal
state guidelines for user charge system and industrial cost recovery system,
and provisions of section
7-1-15 of this chapter. (Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
   (Q)   Any persons violating the provisions of this section shall be subject
to a penalty pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this code. Each day
that such violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 23/2016, 1-3-2017)
7-1-15: WASTEWATER CHARGES:
   (A)   Basis For Wastewater Charges: The wastewater charge for the use of and
for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the city shall consist of
a service charge, a capital improvement charge, a basic user charge for
operation and maintenance plus replacement, and a surcharge, if applicable.
   The service charge shall not be less than that computed by dividing the
annual debt service costs, including minimum required depreciation and reserve
accounts, by the total number of users. Through further divisions, the
quarterly minimum required service charge can be computed.
   The capital improvement charge shall be based on a quarterly charge to each
customer of the system to apply toward future capital improvement projects.
   The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by water
meters and/or sewage meters for wastes having the following normal
concentrations:
      1.   A five (5) day, twenty degree centigrade (20°C) biochemical oxygen
demand (BOD) of two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l).
      2.   A suspended solids (SS) content of two hundred fifty milligrams per
liter (250 mg/l)
It shall consist of operation and maintenance costs plus replacement and shall
not be less than that computed as follows:
      1.   Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and
maintain the wastewater facilities, including replacement of selected
equipment, for all work categories.
      2.   Proportion the estimated costs to wastewater facility categories by
volume, suspended solids and BOD, if possible.
      3.   Estimate wastewater volume, pounds of SS and pounds of BOD to be
treated.
      4.   Proportion the estimated costs to customer classes by volume,
suspended solids and BOD.
      5.   Compute costs per one hundred (100) cubic feet for normal sewage
strength.
      6.   Compute surcharge costs per one hundred (100) cubic feet per
milligrams per liter in excess of normal sewage strength for BOD and SS.
   A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed the normal
concentrations for BOD (200 mg/l) and SS (250 mg/l). The surcharge will be
based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters for all
wastes which exceed the two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l) and two
hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l) concentration for BOD and SS,
respectively. Subsection (F) of this section specifies the procedure to compute
a surcharge.
   The service charge, the capital improvement charge, the basic user charge,
and the surcharge are all computed as shown on the attached "Engineering Data"
sheets, which are hereby made a part of this chapter.
   The adequacy of the wastewater charges shall be reviewed annually by
certified public accountants for the city in their annual audit report. The
wastewater charges shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in service
costs, in operation and maintenance costs, including replacement costs, or in
administrative and reserve costs.
   (B)   Measurement Of Flow: The volume of flow used for computing basic user
charges and surcharges shall be the metered water consumption read to the
nearest whole cubic foot.
      1.   If the person discharging waters into the public sewers procures any
part, or all, of his water from sources other than the city waterworks system,
all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person shall
install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by the
city for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these
other sources.
      2.   Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required
by the city if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered
water consumption records.
      3.   Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be
installed, owned and maintained by the person. Following approval and
installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is canceled,
without the consent of the city.
   (C)   Minimum User Charge: There shall be and there is hereby established a
minimum user charge (including a service charge and a basic user charge) for
the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the city. A
minimum user charge of twenty eight dollars fifty cents ($28.50) per quarter
shall be applied to all users whose water consumption does not exceed five
hundred (500) cubic feet per quarter. The minimum user charge consists of
twenty three dollars seventy five cents ($23.75) for the service charge, three
dollars ($3.00) for the capital improvement charge, and one dollar seventy five
cents ($1.75) for operation, maintenance and replacement for the first five
hundred (500) cubic feet. A basic user rate of thirty five cents ($0.35) per
one hundred (100) cubic feet shall be applied to all users for water
consumption over five hundred (500) cubic feet per quarter.
   (D)   Flat Rate Charge: All nonmetered residential users of the wastewater
facilities shall pay a minimum flat rate charge consisting of twenty three
dollars seventy five cents ($23.75) per quarter to cover the costs of the
service charge, three dollars ($3.00) for the capital improvement charge, and
the basic user charge of thirty five cents ($0.35) per one hundred (100) cubic
feet. The flat rate charge will allow a maximum of two thousand five hundred
(2,500) cubic feet per quarter; and is hereby established to be thirty five
dollars fifty cents ($35.50) per quarter. In the event the twelve (12) month
average use of the wastewater facilities is determined by the city to be in
excess of two thousand five hundred (2,500) cubic feet per quarter, the city
may require such flat rate user to install metering devices on the water supply
or sewer main to measure the amount of service supplied.
   (E)   Surcharge Rate: The rates or surcharges for BOD and SS shall be as
follows:
      1.   For BOD, a surcharge rate of $0.0754 per pound shall be applied for
a waste strength in excess of two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l).
      2.   For SS, a surcharge rate of $0.0430 per pound shall be applied for a
waste strength in excess of two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l).
   (F)   Computing Of Surcharge: The concentration of wastes used for computing
surcharges shall be established by waste sampling. Waste sampling shall be
performed as often as may be deemed necessary by the city and shall be binding
as a basis for surcharges. The surcharge shall be the sum of subsections (F)1
and (F)2 of this section computed as follows:
      1.   For BOD, multiply the surcharge rate by 8.34 (conversion factor for
number of pounds per gallon) multiplied by .0007481 million gallons (100 cubic
feet = 748.1 gallons). This number is then multiplied by the concentration
amount above the allowable two hundred milligrams per liter (200 mg/l),
multiplied by the number of one hundred (100) cubic foot units contributed for
the day. This yields a surcharge per day for BOD (in cost per 100 cubic feet
per milligrams per liter in excess).
      2.   For suspended solids, multiply the surcharge rate by 8.34
(conversion factor for number of pounds per gallons) multiplied by .0007481
million gallons (100 cubic feet = 748.1 gallons). This number is then
multiplied by the concentration amount above the allowable two hundred fifty
milligrams per liter (250 mg/l), multiplied by the number of one hundred (100)
cubic foot units contributed for the day. This yields a surcharge per day for
suspended solids (in cost per 100 cubic feet per milligrams per liter in
excess).
   (G)   Computation Of Wastewater Charge: The wastewater charge shall be
computed by the following formula:
      W = SC + CIC + (V times BUR) + S
   Where:
 
W   = Amount of wastewater charged ($) per billing period
SC  = Service charge (subsection (A))
CIC = Capital improvement charge (subsection (A))
V   = Wastewater volume for the billing period
BUR = Basic user rate for operation, maintenance and replacement (subsection
      (C))
S   = Amount of surcharge (subsections (E) and (F))
 
(Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-16: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   (A)   Bills: Said rates or charges for service shall be payable quarterly.
The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service
shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to such premises
and the service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the
condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the services are
jointly and severally liable therefor to the city. Bills for sewer service
shall be sent out by the city clerk on the first day of the month succeeding
the period for which the service is billed.
   (B)   Nonresidential Use: When sewage treatment service is made available to
nonresident users, the rates therefor shall be based on the formula as set
forth in section
7-1-15 of this chapter multiplied by 1.5.
   (C)   Delinquent Bills: If the charges for such services are not paid within
thirty (30) days after the rendition of the bill for such services, such
services shall be considered delinquent and a notice of such effect shall be
mailed by the city clerk to the owner, occupant and/or user of such premises.
   (D)   Lien Notice Of Delinquency And Termination Of Service: Whenever a bill
for sewer service remains delinquent for ten (10) days for quarterly service,
the city clerk shall cause services to be discontinued without further notice
and such services shall not be reinstated until all claims are settled. The
city clerk may file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien
claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises
served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien
for this amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by
the bill.
   The failure of the city clerk to record such lien or to mail such notice or
the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to
foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned in the foregoing item.
   (E)   Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges
shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be
applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the
foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill-in-equity in
the name of the city. The city attorney may, upon authorization of the city
council, institute such proceedings in the name of the city in any court having
jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has
remained unpaid for ninety (90) days, after it has been rendered.
   (F)   Revenues: All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the
sewerage system shall be deposited in the water and sewer fund of the city. All
such revenues and monies shall be held by the city treasurer separate and apart
from his private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the city
and all of said sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the
city treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at
such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the city.
Said treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner
provided by statute of the "revised cities and villages act", effective January
1942.
   The revenue received by the city from the sewer permit and inspection fee
and the sewer expansion and extension connection fee shall be used by the city
for its sewer purposes, with primary application thereof being made to the
necessary expansion of the works of the sewer system to meet the requirements
of new or additional users thereof. Such funds shall be placed, until they are
used, into a fund which is designated as the "water and sewer fund".
   (G)   Accounts: The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of
accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete
and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewer
system, and at regular annual intervals, he shall cause to be made an audit by
an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewer system.
The financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the
following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for
the current fiscal year.
      2.   Billing data to show total number of gallons billed.
      3.   Debt services for the next succeeding fiscal year.
      4.   Number of users connected to the system.
      5.   Number of nonmetered users.
      6.   A list of users discharging nondomestic wastes (industrial users)
and volume of waste discharged.
   (H)   Notice Of Rates: A copy of this section and section
7-1-15 of this chapter properly certified by the city treasurer, shall be filed
in the office of the recorder of deeds of Mercer County, and shall be deemed
notice to all owners of real estate of the charges of the sewer system of said
city on their properties. (Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
   (I)   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
fined pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this code. (Ord. 23/2016,
1-3-2017)
   (J)   Access To Records: The Illinois environmental protection agency, or
its authorized representative, shall have access to any books, documents,
papers and records of the city for the purpose of making audit, examination,
excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the
special and general conditions to any state grant.
   (K)   Change In Occupancy: Any user requesting a termination of service
shall give written notice to the city ten (10) days prior to the time such
termination of service is desired. Responsibility for payment for sewer service
prior to the date of termination shall be with the property owners as well as
the user. There shall be no charge for transferring the sewer service to the
subsequent user.
   (L)   Notification: Each user will be notified, at least annually, in
conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the user
charges which are attributable to wastewater treatment services.
   (M)   Appeals: The method of computation of rates and service charges
established for user charges shall be made available to a user within seven (7)
days of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over the method
used or in the computations thereof shall be remedies by the city within
fifteen (15) days after notification of a formal written appeal outlining the
discrepancies. (Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-17: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   (A)   The city and other duly authorized employees of the city, the Illinois
environmental protection agency, and the U.S. environmental protection agency,
bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all
properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling,
and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The city or its
representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes,
including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other
industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of
discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment.
   (B)   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection (A) of this section, the city or duly authorized employees of the
city, the Illinois environmental protection agency, and the U.S. environmental
protection agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the person and the person shall be held harmless for injury or
death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the person against
loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims
and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the person
and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be
caused by negligence or failure of the person to maintain safe conditions as
required in subsection
7-1-14(L) of this chapter.
   (C)   The city and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying
within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement,
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved.
   (D)   Employees of the sewerage system shall have the right of access to any
premises served by the sewerage system for the purpose of reading any meters at
the regular prescribed intervals or for the purpose of making inspections in
order to maintain in good condition and provide for the protection of said
sewerage system and the efficient management thereof. Where such inspections
are not of an immediate or urgent nature, employees of the sewerage system
shall arrange for appointments mutually convenient to the persons of the
premises served and said employees. Any person refusing to permit the said
employees of the sewerage system to the above described right of access to his
premises shall be subject to cessation of sewage services until the required
opportunity to inspect is accorded the officers and employees of the city.
(Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-18: OPENINGS IN STREETS:
All openings made in sidewalks or roadways, for the purpose of constructing
house drains or private sewers, shall be surrounded and efficiently protected
at all hours by ample and sufficient barriers, on which red signal lights shall
be placed and maintained at nighttime, together with such additional precaution
as may be deemed necessary by the street committee for the absolute protection
of the traveling public. The conditions of this clause are imperative and drain
layers will be held responsible for all claims that may arise from damages to
persons or property following neglect or violation of any of its provisions.
(Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-19: SPECIFICATIONS AND RULES:
The mayor and city council are hereby authorized to make such rules and
regulations consistent with this chapter for the connections to the sewerage
system, specifying the types and sizes of pipes and all the other appurtenances
and extensions thereto, and amend the same from time to time as may be deemed
necessary. All service pipes and connections to the sewerage system shall
comply with the said specifications and rules for connection to the sewerage
system and any person, persons, firm or corporation failing to comply with said
specifications and rules shall be subject to a penalty as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-20: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE AND PENALTIES:
   (A)   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently
break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure,
appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage works of the city. Any
person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under the
charge of disorderly conduct.
   (B)   Any person found to be violating any provisions of this chapter except
subsection (A) of this section shall be served by the city with written notice
stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for
the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of
time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violation. For the purposes
of this section a reasonable time limit shall be considered and deemed to be a
period of not more than ninety (90) days, as the circumstances of the
particular violation and the action necessary to correction thereof may
dictate. (Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
   (C)   Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit
provided for in subsection (B) of this section shall be fined pursuant to title
12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this code. (Ord. 23/2016, 1-3-2017)
   (D)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city
by reason of such violation. (Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-21: VALIDITY:
The validity of any section, clause, sentence or provision of this chapter
shall not effect the validity of any other part of this chapter which can be
given effect without such invalid part or parts. (Ord. 14/88, 3-20-1989)
7-1-22: ENFORCEMENT:
   (A)   A copy of the ordinance codified herein properly certified by the city
clerk, shall be filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county of
Mercer, and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their
liability for services supplied to any user of the service of the waterworks
and sewerage systems of said city on their properties, and it shall be the duty
of the city clerk and such other officers of this city to take all action
necessary or required by the laws of the state of Illinois thereunto enabling
to file all claims and liens for money due to the city and to prosecute and
enforce such claims in the manner, form and time as permitted by the laws of
the state of Illinois.
   (B)   This ordinance shall be published in pamphlet form by the city clerk
and shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and
publication as provided by the statutes of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 14/88,
3-20-1989)
CHAPTER 2
FOOD DISPLAYS
(Rep. by Ord. 23/2016, 1-3-2017)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE
SECTION:
7-3-1:   Throwing And Dumping Waste Prohibited
7-3-2:   Containers Required
7-3-3:   Nonresidential Waste Collection And Disposal
7-3-4:   Yard Waste
7-3-1: THROWING AND DUMPING WASTE PROHIBITED:
No person shall throw, dump, or deposit any waste in any street, alley, or on
public property in the city. No person shall cast or leave exposed any waste in
or about any private premises or on any lot, street, or alley or about any
sewer or storm sewer in the city. (Ord. 11/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3-2: CONTAINERS REQUIRED:
No person shall permit any waste to accumulate on his or her premises whether
residential, commercial, or industrial, except in containers or receptacles
appropriate for the type of waste involved excepting yard waste, tree and shrub
branches and trimmings, and construction debris. The term "container" includes
garbage cans, metal or plastic, with lids fitting nearly airtight and
watertight as practicable. It also includes toters having a capacity of not
less than thirty five (35) gallons nor more than forty (40) gallons, with an
attached lid, a handle and wheels having a minimum of six inches (6") in
diameter. And it also includes recyclable containers or bins which need not
have lids. Every person in possession of a dwelling unit, including multi-
family dwellings of four (4) units or less, shall be required to have
accumulations of refuse and waste collected and disposed of regularly and
systematically at least once per week by a residential waste hauler duly
licensed by the city, except for recyclable materials, which shall be collected
and disposed of by a duly licensed residential waste hauler at least weekly.
(Ord. 11/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3-3: NONRESIDENTIAL WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
Other than owners of dwelling units as provided above, it shall be the duty of
every property owner, including multi-family dwellings of more than four (4)
units, and commercial, business, and industrial establishments, to provide for
the collection and removal of all waste of any quantity whatsoever generated on
such property at least once per week, or more frequently if required, so as to
avoid health hazards or unreasonable accumulations of waste. This duty shall
also extend to the lessee of any such type of property. (Ord. 11/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3-4: YARD WASTE:
   A.   The City may, from time to time, provide a yard waste disposal site for
use by City of Aledo Residents. Only grass clippings, leaves, tree limbs and
trimmings, and landscape waste generated from properties within the City of
Aledo shall be accepted at the disposal site. Treated lumber, garbage bags, and
other materials are prohibited. Dumping at the City's yard waste disposal site
of yard and tree waste generated from properties outside of the City of Aledo
is prohibited.
   B.   Dumping by commercial businesses of tree limbs and trimmings and other
tree waste shall be subject to the fees set forth in Section
13-1-1 of the Aledo City Code.
(Ord. 11/2024, 7-1-2024)
ARTICLE A. RESIDENTIAL WASTE HAULERS
SECTION:
7-3A-1:    License Required
7-3A-2:    Collection Without License Prohibited
7-3A-3:    Suspension Or Revocation
7-3A-4:    Duration And Annual Fee
7-3A-5:    Application
7-3A-6:    Duty To Update Information
7-3A-7:    Conditions Of License
7-3A-8:    Recycling Requirements
7-3A-9:    Waste And Recycling Prices
7-3A-10:    Monthly Reports And Right Of Inspection
7-3A-11:    Authority To Promulgate Rules
7-3A-12:    Nonresidential Waste Collection And Disposal Requirements
7-3A-13:    Scavenger's License Required
7-3A-14:    Burning And Burying Of Certain Waste Prohibited
7-3A-15:    Soft And Hard Yard Waste Excluded
7-3A-16:    Construction Debris
7-3A-17:    Hazardous Waste
7-3A-18:    Nonresidential Collections
7-3A-19:    Violation And Penalties
7-3A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Every person engaged in the business of residential waste hauling within the
City shall obtain a residential waste hauling license. Such license shall be
issued by the City Clerk in accordance with the requirements of this article.
The word "person" when used in this section or any other section of this
article shall include a partnership, limited partnership, corporation, limited
liability company, or any other type of entity engaged in the business of
residential waste hauling within the City. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-2: COLLECTION WITHOUT LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No person shall collect residential waste, or advertise such services, within
the City without having a valid license issued under this article. (Ord. 12/98,
4-5-1999)
7-3A-3: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
All licenses or permits issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall
be suspended or revoked, and all refusals to issue a license or permit shall be
made, as a result of a violation of any of the provisions of this article.
(Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-4: DURATION AND ANNUAL FEE:
Each residential waste hauling license shall expire on April 30 of each year
unless renewed in accordance with this article. Each applicant for a waste
hauling license shall pay, in advance, an annual fee pursuant to title 13,
"Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. (Ord. 15/2017, 6-5-2017)
7-3A-5: APPLICATION:
The application for and renewal of a residential waste hauling license shall
include the following information:
   (A)   Name and phone number of the business operating the vehicles;
   (B)   The name of the Manager of the business;
   (C)   The address of the business;
   (D)   Type of each collection vehicle (pickup, dump truck, semitruck, etc.);
   (E)   Proof of current general and automobile liability insurance in the
form of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to
do business in the State of Illinois in the amounts required by State law,
reporting the vehicle identification number of each collection vehicle used by
the business residential waste hauler within the City; and
   (F)   If the applicant is or will be collecting on a regular basis from
residential dwellings, including multi-family dwellings of four (4) units or
less, a description of how and by whom recyclables will be collected. (Ord. 12/
98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-6: DUTY TO UPDATE INFORMATION:
The licensee shall notify the city in writing within fourteen (14) days
following a change in any information contained in the licensee's application
or any change in the information furnished by the licensee after its
application pursuant to the requirements of this article. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-
1999)
7-3A-7: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
All persons required to have a license under this article shall comply with the
following conditions:
   (A)   All licensees must provide an integrated service combining and
including a minimum of weekly curbside refuse collection and weekly recyclable
collection. Neither service may be made available individually;
   (B)   All vehicles used for residential waste hauling shall display the
license upon the vehicle as directed by the director of public works and
utilities;
   (C)   Every vehicle utilized by a person required to have a license under
this article and used for the transfer of residential waste through the streets
of the city shall have and utilize a watertight bed or receptacle having a
closed cover and be so constructed that no portion of the waste conveyed
therein shall be scattered or left in or upon the sidewalks, streets, alleys,
or public grounds of the city;
   (D)   No person required to have a license under this article shall deposit
or store any residential waste, when collected, within the corporate limits of
the city;
   (E)   No vehicle used for the collection of residential waste by a person
required to have a license under this article shall be allowed to become
offensive to the sense of smell of a person of ordinary sensibilities. Such
vehicle shall be cleaned inside and out at regular intervals;
   (F)   Every vehicle utilized by a person required to have a license under
this article hauling garbage or putrescible rubbish must be evacuated of its
contents within twenty four (24) hours of the deposit of such garbage or
putrescible rubbish;
   (G)   No vehicle utilized by a person required to have a license under this
article shall be parked overnight in or adjacent to residential areas outside
of an enclosed structure. If a vehicle licensed under this article is stored in
a residential district within an enclosed structure, the owner of the vehicle
shall have a rodent control plan approved by and on file with the director of
public works and utilities;
   (H)   No person required to have a license under this article shall transfer
residential waste from one vehicle to another vehicle on any city street or in
such a manner as to cause the release of waste onto any property;
   (I)   Any person required to be licensed by this article shall maintain in
full force and effect general liability insurance, vehicle liability insurance,
workers' compensation insurance, and unemployment insurance with insurance
companies licensed to do business in the state of Illinois in the amounts
required by state law. Upon request of the city, such a person shall produce
evidence of such coverage; and
   (J)   Upon request by the city, any person required to have a license under
this article shall provide the city, in writing, with schedules of rates in
effect at the time of the request. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-8: RECYCLING REQUIREMENTS:
All persons who provide residential waste hauling services to residential
dwellings, including multi-family dwellings of four (4) units or less, must
provide the following services:
   (A)   Pick up of recyclable materials, including at least newsprint, clear
glass jars or bottles, tin cans, aluminum cans, steel cans, and HDPE no. 1 and
no. 2 plastic containers; and
   (B)   Once collected, all recyclables must be processed for transfer to the
secondary materials market by either the residential waste hauler or a material
recovery center. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-9: WASTE AND RECYCLING PRICES:
Each licensee shall set one price for its combined waste and recyclable
services, which price shall not be higher than the price charged to those
customers for waste pick up services who elect not to recycle. Recycling
services shall not be separately priced by any licensee. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-10: MONTHLY REPORTS AND RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
   (A)   Every licensee shall file a monthly report with the Director of Public
Works and Utilities in a form designated by the Director of Public Works and
Utilities which states the following information:
      1.   How much recyclable material was collected; and
      2.   Where and to whom the recyclable material was disposed, or if
stored, where stored. If stored, such licensee shall store the recyclables
under conditions which will not degrade the quality of the recyclable
materials.
   Such reports shall be filed no later than the twentieth day following the
month for which a report is due and all such reports shall be signed under
penalties of perjury.
   (B)   The licensee shall also provide certification by the recycling
processor at least quarterly of the quantity of recyclables which have been
delivered by the licensee from the City.
   (C)   The licensee shall admit, for the purpose of making an inspection, any
officer or employee of the City who is authorized or directed to make such
inspection at any reasonable time that such admission is requested for the
purpose of ensuring compliance with this article. Such right of inspection
shall extend to the place of first delivery of recyclables. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-
1999)
7-3A-11: AUTHORITY TO PROMULGATE RULES:
   (A)   The Director of Public Works and Utilities is empowered to promulgate
rules for the following purposes:
      1.   To designate acceptable areas along or upon City rights-of-way for
the deposit for pick up of recyclable material;
      2.   To promulgate such other rules relative to recycling as are
reasonably necessary to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens
of the City; and
      3.   To designate procedures or forms necessary to fulfill the
requirements of this article.
   (B)   Such rules may be adopted and/or amended from time to time by the
Director of Public Works and Utilities and such rules and regulations or
amendments shall be deemed effective thirty (30) days after the date of written
notification to the City Council of such amendments unless the City Council
shall disapprove of all or any such rules and regulations or amendments within
such thirty (30) day period.
   (C)   No person shall violate any rules promulgated by the Director of
Public Works and Utilities which have been approved or deemed approved pursuant
to subsection (B) of this section. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-12: NONRESIDENTIAL WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be the duty of every property owner or lessee thereof to provide not
only for the collection and removal of waste generated by multi-family
dwellings of more than four (4) units, commercial, business and industrial
properties, but to also effect the proper placement of containers storing waste
thereon so as to not be visible from the street or adjacent properties if
reasonably possible. All areas set aside for the collection of waste shall be
so located as to not be unsightly in appearance or offensive in odor and shall
be so maintained as to be flyproof when the nature of the waste involved so
requires that condition and to prevent waste from scattering and becoming
windblown when the nature of the waste poses that threat. It shall be the duty
of every property owner or lessee thereof in providing for the collection and
removal of waste, in any quantity whatsoever generated by any of the above
described properties, to see that such collection is affected either by a
residential waste hauler duly licensed by the City who also offers commercial
waste pick up services or by a scavenger duly licensed to do business in the
City pursuant to section
7-3A-13 of this article. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-13: SCAVENGER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, either as principal or agent, shall engage in the business of
collecting and hauling waste generated from multi- family dwellings of more
than four (4) units, and commercial, business, and industrial properties
located in the City without having first obtained a license as a scavenger. As
a condition to obtaining a scavenger's license, each applicant must comply with
the same insurance requirements for a residential waste hauler in the City.
Each applicant for a scavenger's license shall pay an annual fee pursuant to
title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code and each scavenger's license shall
expire on April 30 of each year unless renewed in accordance with this article.
(Ord. 15/2017, 6-5-2017)
7-3A-14: BURNING AND BURYING OF CERTAIN WASTE PROHIBITED 1 :
No person shall burn or bury any waste in the city except that leaves and tree,
shrub, and brush trimmings may be burned by residential owners or lessees
thereof. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  5-2-1 of this code.
7-3A-15: SOFT AND HARD YARD WASTE EXCLUDED:
No residential waste hauler duly licensed by the city hereunder shall be
required to collect and dispose of hard yard waste (tree and shrub branches and
trimmings) or soft yard waste (grass clippings, leaves, prunings of small
diameter, green stemmed shrubs, and plant stalks). (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-16: CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS:
The removal of construction debris shall be the responsibility of the owner of
the premises and the person or building contractor performing the construction
work. The owner and the person or building contractor may employ a licensed
scavenger to remove such construction debris, provided the scavenger shall not
remove waste generated by the occupants of any single-family residential
dwelling or any multi-family dwelling of four (4) units or less whether or not
any such dwelling unit is under repair or construction. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-17: HAZARDOUS WASTE:
The applicable state regulations shall govern the removal and disposal of all
hazardous waste. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-18: NONRESIDENTIAL COLLECTIONS:
Waste collection and disposal service to nonresidential establishments and the
collection of waste other than from single-family residential dwellings,
including multi-family dwellings of four (4) units or less, shall be performed
either by a residential waste hauler duly licensed by the city for residential
waste removal or by a scavenger duly licensed to do business in the city in
accordance with section
7-3A-13 of this article at such schedules and rates as may be mutually agreed
upon between either the licensed residential waste hauler or the licensed
scavenger, depending upon whatever the case may be, and such nonresidential
accounts. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
7-3A-19: VIOLATION AND PENALTIES:
   (A)   In addition to the revocation or suspension provided in section
7-3A-3 of this article, any person who violates any provision of this article
shall be subject to a fine pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this
code. (Ord. 23/2016, 1-3-2017)
   (B)   The suspension or revocation of a residential waste hauler's license
by the city or fine imposed by the city in an administrative hearing presided
over by the mayor of the city shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so
as to bar any court imposed fine from being enforced. (Ord. 12/98, 4-5-1999)
CHAPTER 4
MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS
SECTION:
7-4-1:   Tests Required
7-4-2:   Dealer Responsible
7-4-3:   Pasteurized Products
7-4-1: TESTS REQUIRED:
No milk or cream or ice cream shall be sold or offered for sale in the city,
for use in said city, either by the producer thereof or any dealer therein
unless the said milk, cream or ice cream shall come from cows which have been
tested for tuberculosis by some recognized state or federal veterinarian within
twelve (12) months next prior to such sale or offer of sale; and no milk, cream
or ice cream shall be sold or offered for sale in the city for use in the city,
either by the producer thereof or any dealer therein that came from a cow that
ever reacted to the tuberculin test or that is infected with tuberculosis.
(Ord. 7/21, 4-4-1922)
7-4-2: DEALER RESPONSIBLE:
It shall be the duty of every person selling or offering to sell milk, cream or
ice cream within the city, for use in said city as a producer or as a dealer in
the same to ascertain whether such product so sold or offered for sale is a
proper product to sell or offer to sell under section
7-4-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 7/21, 4-4-1922)
7-4-3: PASTEURIZED PRODUCTS:
This chapter shall not apply to milk or cream which has been properly
pasteurized nor to ice cream made from pasteurized milk or cream. (Ord. 7/21,
4-4-1922)
CHAPTER 5
PUBLIC HEALTH NUISANCES
SECTION:
7-5-1:   Nuisances Prohibited
7-5-1: NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
No person, firm or corporation shall allow or permit on their premises, whether
owned, rented, or occupied, in the city of Aledo, state of Illinois, any of the
following conditions:
   (A)   Trash and/or garbage to be strewn about so as to cause offensive odors
or to be detrimental to the health of any person or persons.
   (B)   Appliances, furniture and mattresses to be strewn about outdoors so as
to cause a health hazard and become a breeding place for rodents.
   (C)   The use of defective garbage cans containing holes.
   (D)   Automobiles in hazardous condition because of their condition,
including, but not limited to, being on blocks, without wheels, broken windows
or with other missing or damaged parts that cause a dangerous condition or
provide a breeding place for rodents. (Ord. 4/76, 7-6-1976)
   (E)   Burning of refuse or garbage, except in an incinerator approved by the
EPA.
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be subject to a fine pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this
code. (Ord. 23/2016, 1-3-2017)
CHAPTER 6
PRIVIES
SECTION:
7-6-1:   Privies Prohibited
7-6-1: PRIVIES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain any outside privy, privy vault or
water closet, within the fire limits of the city, as the same are now, or
hereafter may be established; and all outside privies, privy vaults or water
closets now existing or being maintained within said fire limits are hereby
declared to be nuisances.
All outside privies, privy vaults or water closets shall be removed and all
excavations under the same, filled with ashes or clean soil; provided, this
chapter shall not apply to the buildings only over such privy vaults, where the
excavations under the same have been filled in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter and the same are in nowise used as privies or water closets, or
receptacles for sewage or offal of any character; and provided further this
chapter shall not apply to outside water closets equipped with flush tanks, and
connected properly by discharge pipes or tile with the city sewer system, nor
to privies or outside water closets on premises not assessed for sewer
improvement purposes. (Ord. 4/11, 9-4-1911)
CHAPTER 7
EATING AND DRINKING ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
7-7-1:   Adoption Of U.S. Public Health Service Ordinance
7-7-1: ADOPTION OF U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE ORDINANCE:
The inspection, grading, regrading and placarding of eating and drinking
establishments within the city or its police jurisdiction, the issuing,
suspension and revocation of permits for the operation of such establishments,
the sale of adulterated, misbranded or unwholesome food and drink and the
enforcement of this chapter shall be regulated in accordance with the terms of
the unabridged form of the 1943 edition of the U.S. public health service
ordinance regulating eating and drinking establishments, three (3) certified
copies of which shall be on file in the office of the clerk; provided however,
that in section 2 of said U.S. public health service ordinance, itinerant
restaurants shall be required to secure a permit.
Provided further, that when any restaurant fails to qualify for any of the
grades specified in the U.S. public health service ordinance the health officer
or other designated official is authorized to suspend the permit or in lieu
thereof to degrade the restaurant and permit its operation during a temporary
period not exceeding thirty (30) days. (1969 Code)
CHAPTER 8
RETAIL SALE PLACEMENT OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS
SECTION:
7-8-1:   Definitions
7-8-2:   Acceptable Locations
7-8-3:   Prohibited Locations
7-8-4:   Fine
7-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the respective meanings ascribed to them:
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust,
or any other legal entity.
   RETAIL BUSINESS: Any person, firm, association, partnership, corporation,
trust, or any other legal entity which offers tobacco products for sale at
retail on its business premises.
   TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco, or
dipping tobacco. (Ord. 2/2004, 5-17-2004)
7-8-2: ACCEPTABLE LOCATIONS:
All tobacco products offered for sale at retail within the city of Aledo must
be displayed on the business premises in a location other than on the counter
where any cash register is maintained and must be displayed in a showcase or
other secured display rack so that clerk assistance is required before any
person wishing to purchase any tobacco products can come into possession of
such tobacco products. (Ord. 2/2004, 5-17-2004)
7-8-3: PROHIBITED LOCATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person selling or offering to sell any tobacco
products at retail on its business premises within the city of Aledo to display
tobacco products on the counter where any cash register is maintained or to
display any tobacco products for sale at retail other than in a showcase or
other secured display rack that requires clerk assistance before any customer
wishing to purchase tobacco products can come into possession of such tobacco
products. (Ord. 2/2004, 5-17-2004)
7-8-4: FINE:
Any person who violates this chapter shall be subject to a fine pursuant to
title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this code. (Ord. 23/2016, 1-3-2017)
CHAPTER 9
HOME KITCHEN OPERATIONS
SECTION:
7-9-1:   Definitions
7-9-2:   Home Kitchen Operations
7-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the definitions found in the Illinois Food
Handling Regulation Enforcement Act, 410 ILCS 625 et seq., are hereby adopted
by reference as if fully set forth herein. (Ord. 01/2020, 1-19-2021)
7-9-2: HOME KITCHEN OPERATIONS:
   (A)   Subject to all applicable city ordinances, including, without
limitation, land use and zoning regulations and privilege taxes, the statutory
provisions contained within the Illinois Food Handling Regulation Enforcement
Act (410 ILCS 625/3.6) regarding home kitchen operations, as now or hereafter
amended are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth herein.
   (B)   The direct sale of baked goods as described in the Illinois Food
Handling Regulation Enforcement Act is hereby authorized, provided the
following conditions are satisfied:
      1.   Monthly gross sales do not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
      2.   The baked goods are non-potentially hazardous baked good, as
described in 410 ILCS 625/3.6(a-5) of the Act.
      3.   A notice is provided to the purchaser that the product was produced
in a home kitchen.
      4.   The food package is affixed with a label or other written notice is
provided to the purchaser that includes:
         (a)   The common or usual name of the food product; and
         (b)   Allergen labeling as specified in federal labeling requirements
by the United States Food and Drug Administration.
      5.   The food is sold directly to the consumer by the home owner or a
family member.
      6.   The food is stored in the residence where it is produced or
packaged. (Ord. 01/2020, 1-19-2021)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
CEMETERY
SECTION:
8-1-1:   Ownership Of Lots
8-1-2:   Control Vested In Corporate Authorities
8-1-3:   Rules And Regulations
8-1-4:   Mausoleum Fees
8-1-5:   Endowment Fund
8-1-6:   Fees
8-1-7:   Interment
8-1-1: OWNERSHIP OF LOTS:
The ownership of the lots as laid out and platted in the cemetery shall be in
the City, unless sold to a person or persons specified and recorded as owners
of lots in the records as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
8-1-2: CONTROL VESTED IN CORPORATE AUTHORITIES:
The control of the cemetery shall be vested in the Corporate Authorities of the
City, which shall be governed by the provisions of this Code. It shall be the
duty of the Corporate Authorities to fix the price of lots in said cemetery,
and to cause to be platted into lots of regular size and shape all of the land
to be designated for such purposes by action of the City Council. The Cemetery
Committee of the City Council may be assigned by the Corporate Authorities to
make such inquiry, review and recommendations as deemed necessary to the best
operation of the Aledo Cemetery. (Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
8-1-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   (A)   The City Council retains at all times the authority to adopt rules and
regulations for cemetery operations. The Cemetery Sexton shall enforce those
rules adopted by the City Council. The Cemetery Sexton shall have authority to
give appropriate direction on day to day operations wherein formal policy has
not been adopted.
   (B)   The cemetery when platted shall show the location of each lot in the
cemetery, and if there be double lots, to show the location of such double lot
or lots. Each lot shall be numbered numerically as shall be deemed best by the
Cemetery Sexton of said cemetery.
   The original plat of said cemetery shall be kept by the Clerk at his office
in the City Hall and shall be properly filed for record in his care and
custody. A copy of said plat shall be kept by the Sexton of the Cemetery.
   Both plats shall show the lots which are sold and unsold and shall be kept
up to date by the Clerk and the Cemetery Sexton respectively. Such records
shall show the location of all lots and the respective price determined
therefor. (Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
   (C)   The sale of all lots of the cemetery shall be by deed from the City,
by its Mayor or authorized designee, under his hand and the Corporate Seal of
the City, and attested to by the Clerk and the signing, sealing, and delivering
of the cemetery deed shall be acknowledged before an officer duly qualified and
authorized to certify such execution of a deed as provided by law. No person,
partnership, corporation, or other type of entity, either directly or
indirectly acting through a trust or any other type of legal arrangement, may
purchase or own an interest in more than one lot (8 burial plots) without first
securing approval of the City's Corporate Authorities. In addition, sale of a
lot by an owner(s) cannot be made without first securing approval of the City's
Corporate Authorities. No such transfer is valid until entered on the cemetery
records maintained by the City for the recording of deeds of conveyance for
cemetery lots, and no such transfer of a lot by sale or otherwise by a lot
owner will be recognized unless the City's Corporate Authorities have consented
to the transfer. All transfers of ownership in lots will be subject to a fee
pursuant to title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code, which must be paid to
the Comptroller when the transfer is recorded. The cemetery grounds are exempt
from taxation and liability of the lot owners for the payment of their debts.
(Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-2017)
   (D)   Proper recording materials shall be provided by the City
administration for the keeping of all records provided by the provisions of
this chapter. Such records, when assembled in book or card form or any other
method deemed desirable, shall be known as the cemetery record of deeds.
   (E)   The Cemetery Sexton shall have the right to determine what plants,
shrubs, or trees, or anything of ornament may be planted or placed on or about
the lots unless otherwise directed by vote of the City Council. All grading and
improvement of lots, all excavations for vaults, the building of foundations,
graves, or any other work if done for a consideration must be done as provided
by the provisions of this chapter and as directed by the Cemetery Sexton. No
person will be allowed to plant trees or shrubs on graves or lots and no tree
or shrub shall be cut down, removed or trimmed, without permission of the
Cemetery Sexton and all planting of flowers, watering, cutting and trimming the
same, or special care of the grass shall be done under the supervision and
authority of the Cemetery Sexton or his designee. All persons are forbidden to
pick or cut flowers on any other lot than their own lot without special
permission from the Sexton of the Cemetery.
   (F)   No fence, or enclosure of any kind, will be permitted on or about
burial lots. The placing of boxes, shells, toys, metal designs and similar
articles upon the graves or lots is inconsistent with the proper keeping of the
grounds, and will not be permitted. Cornerstones shall be set on a level with
the surface of the ground, and the Cemetery Sexton is authorized to take down
and remove fences surrounding lots, and in exchange to give and set
cornerstones properly marked, also to grade and improve such lots free of
expense to owners. Where fences or other structures on any lot have, by reason
of neglect, become objectionable in the judgment of the Cemetery Sexton, they
are authorized to have the same removed, in which case the outline of the lot
shall be preserved by cornerstones, or other proper landmarks.
   (G)   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to do any labor in or
about any lot or ground within the cemetery except by authority and under the
direction of the Cemetery Sexton. (Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
   (H)   Any work done by an employee of the City in the cemetery or elsewhere,
including but not limited to, the moving of bodies, marking of graves or
monuments, repairing markings on monuments, digging graves, setting vaults, or
any other work in connection therewith, shall be billed by the Sexton in the
name of the City against the person or persons ordering the same pursuant to
title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code, and such bill shall be delivered to
and collected by the finance authority designated for the collection and
receipt of City funds. (Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-2017)
   (I)   The care of the grounds, setting of monuments, grave markers and care
of graves shall be under the supervision of the Sexton and according to the
regulations and specifications of this chapter and the policies adopted by the
Corporate Authorities of the City.
   (J)   Any owner, or part owner, of a lot has the right to give permission,
either in person or by a written order, for the burial of the remains of other
than his immediate family in his lot, or portion thereof, but not for money or
other consideration, or profit. (Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
8-1-4: MAUSOLEUM FEES:
No bodies, ashes, or remains shall be temporarily kept in any mausoleum
receiving vault or crypt for more than fifteen (15) days unless special
permission is granted by the Cemetery Sexton for an extension of time. A fee
shall be charged for the opening and closing of a mausoleum vault or crypt
recognized by the City of Aledo when any body, ashes, or remains is either
placed therein or removed therefrom for any reason. Such fee shall be charged
pursuant to title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. (Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-
2017)
8-1-5: ENDOWMENT FUND:
   (A)   A portion of all fees collected pursuant to this chapter and title 13,
"Schedule Of Fees", of this Code shall be deposited to the Cemetery Endowment
Fund. (Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-2017)
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the City to care for all cemetery lots which
are sold hereafter; to mow the grass and weeds from the same and to keep said
lot or lots in general good condition.
   (C)   The City finance authority shall keep a permanent record showing the
money received by him for endowment purposes, from whom it is received and the
particular lot or lots to which said several endowments apply. Such records
shall be kept by the Comptroller as required by law. The City finance authority
shall report annually to the Corporate Authorities as to the financial
activities of the Endowment Fund. (Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
8-1-6: FEES:
All fees and charges for cemetery sales, operations and services shall be
established by ordinance or resolution of the Corporate Authorities, and set
forth in title 13, "Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. (Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-2017)
8-1-7: INTERMENT:
Each interment of human remains shall be placed in a single box made of durable
material and meeting industry standards for such use and a vault constructed of
concrete, steel or other like durable material. No wood vault shall be
permitted. No grave liner shall be required for any interment of human remains,
but may be used if requested by the family. The Cemetery Sexton shall have the
authority to deny the use of any container or vault if such item, in his
opinion, does not meet industry standards, or, is detrimental to the operations
or appearance of the cemetery or the health, safety and welfare of the cemetery
staff or to the community. Such denial may be appealed to the City Council.
(Ord. 03-17-08-1, 3-17-2008)
CHAPTER 2
DATUM PLANE
SECTION:
8-2-1:   Datum Plane Established
8-2-1: DATUM PLANE ESTABLISHED:
A datum plane to govern elevations, be and is hereby established in the city.
Said datum plane is a horizontal plane passing seven hundred thirty seven feet
(737.00') below the United States geological survey bench mark located in the
northwest portion of the Mercer County court house ground, being a fixed
galvanize iron pipe with bronze metal cap, bearing the inscription, "U.S.
Geological Survey B.M. Elevation above sea datum 737 ft". (Ord. 2/26, 5-3-1926)
CHAPTER 3
PARKS
SECTION:
8-3-1:   Park Rules And Regulations
8-3-2:   Central Park Shelter
8-3-3:   Smoking Prohibited In Central Park
8-3-1: PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations shall govern all parks owned and maintained
by the City:
   (A)   No person shall walk, stand or lie upon any portion of any enclosed
grounds, public square or park, laid out or appropriated to the cultivation of
shrubbery, grass or flowers, or trample upon, pull up, or otherwise injure or
destroy any such grass, flowers or shrubbery, or turn loose any horse, cow, ox,
ass, mule, sheep, hog or other animal into or upon any such public park or
other public grounds owned and controlled by the City, or work or climb upon
any fence or railing surrounding such public grounds or any part thereof, or
erect any booth or stall thereat without permission from the City authorities.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Superintendent, and he is hereby
authorized and required to superintend and control the parks, public squares
and grounds owned and improved by the City, to maintain and keep up the fences
surrounding the same, and to trim and keep in proper order the trees, walks and
shrubbery therein, and perform such other duties as may be required of him by
the Mayor and Council.
   (C)   It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person, except the officials or
employees of the City to throw anything into any fountain in any park or public
grounds in the City or to wade or walk in or upon said fountains, or to permit
dogs or other animals to be in same, and it shall be unlawful for any person,
except said officers or employees of the City, to molest, or in any manner
disturb the fish swimming in said fountains; or to pick, cut, mangle, trample
upon, or in any manner to injure or mutilate any flower, shrub, tree, or
ornamental plant of whatsoever kind growing in or upon any park or public
ground in the City.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to either enter or occupy any part
of any premises constituting a City park owned and maintained by the City
between dusk and dawn each day. In the event that any person violates the
provision of the foregoing curfew imposed on any and all parks owned and
maintained by the City, such person shall be fined pursuant to title 12,
"Schedule Of Fines", of this Code. (Ord. 1/01, 6-6-1901; amd. Ord. 28/79; Ord.
24/2016, 1-3-2017; Ord. 19/2021, 11-1-2021)
8-3-2: CENTRAL PARK SHELTER:
The use of the bandshell and pavilion located in Central Park, and related
audio equipment shall be subject to payment of a fee pursuant to title 13,
"Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. (Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-2017)
8-3-3: SMOKING PROHIBITED IN CENTRAL PARK:
   (A)   Prohibition: Smoking is hereby prohibited in the City owned park known
as "Central Park" located at the northeast intersection of South College Avenue
and S.E. 3rd Street.
   (B)   Posting Of Signs: The Director of Public Works shall post one or more
signs in Central Park clearly stating that smoking is prohibited and violations
are punishable by fine.
   (C)   Enforcement: Any police officer who observes a violation of this
section may issue a citation in the same manner as with other ordinance
violations. (Ord. 14/2010, 5-3-2010)
   (D)   Penalties: A person found to have committed a violation of this
section shall be fined pursuant to title 12, "Schedule Of Fines", of this Code.
(Ord. 24/2016, 1-3-2017)
CHAPTER 4
RAILROADS
(Rep. by Ord. 24/2016, 1-3-2017)
CHAPTER 5
SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
8-5-1:   Construction Requirements
8-5-2:   Supervision
8-5-3:   Costs Of Construction
8-5-4:   Repairing Of Sidewalks
8-5-5:   Condemn Sidewalks
8-5-6:   Financing Of Sidewalk Construction
8-5-1: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any sidewalk to be constructed or renewed within the
corporate limits of the City of Aledo unless cement is used in said
construction or renewal of said sidewalk and said construction or renewal work
is done in accordance to the specifications as set forth in ordinance codified
herein pertaining to sidewalks, including, but not limited to, specifications
and regulations as the City Council and/or the Director of Public Works and
Utilities may from time to time require for sidewalk construction.
All sidewalks hereinafter constructed or renewed shall conform to and be laid
in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted by the Illinois Department
of Transportation, in its "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction", duly adopted on July 1, 1976, and as may be amended by said
department from time to time, and said construction or renewal of sidewalks
shall conform to all other rules and regulations that the City Council and/or
the Director of Public Works and Utilities may adopt from time to time
pertaining to construction of sidewalks within the City of Aledo. (Ord. 2/78,
6-19-1978)
8-5-2: SUPERVISION:
All sidewalks hereinafter constructed, renewed or repaired shall be
constructed, renewed or repaired under the direction and supervision of the
Director of Public Works and Utilities, or a proper officer of the City acting
for the said Director of Public Works and Utilities. (Ord. 2/78, 6-19-1978)
8-5-3: COSTS OF CONSTRUCTION:
The City shall pay fifty percent (50%) of the construction cost or costs of
renewing any sidewalk within the City subject to a limitation that the City
shall not be obligated to pay more than twelve dollars ($12.00) per square foot
for its share for the construction or renewal of any sidewalk within the City.
However, as to that portion of any sidewalk that is constructed or renewed at
the corner of a City block and which runs from the curb thereto to a
perpendicular line created by the nearest edge of a cross sidewalk to the said
curb which exists or where said cross sidewalk would exist if constructed in a
proper place, the City shall pay one hundred percent (100%) of said
construction or renewal costs. (Ord. 34/2017, 12-4-2017)
8-5-4: REPAIRING OF SIDEWALKS:
Except for minor repairs, it shall be unlawful to repair any sidewalk now
constructed in the City with any material other than cement. The Director of
Public Works and Utilities shall have sole authority to determine if any
particular repair work for any existing sidewalk is minor or incidental
resulting in no requirement that cement be used for said proposed repair work.
(Ord. 2/78, 6-19-1978)
8-5-5: CONDEMN SIDEWALKS:
The City Council shall have the power, upon the recommendation of the Director
of Public Works and Utilities to condemn any and all sidewalk or sidewalks now
constructed in the City, when the same shall be in such state of decay or
repair as to be dangerous or unsuited any longer for the purposes of a
sidewalk, and the passing of an ordinance, and approving thereof, for the
construction or renewal of any sidewalk, shall operate and be construed as a
condemnation of the sidewalk then existing along the proposed line of the
sidewalk provided to be constructed or renewed by such ordinance. (Ord. 2/78,
6-19-1978)
8-5-6: FINANCING OF SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION:
Upon proper application to the City Clerk by all of the persons and/or entities
owning a particular lot upon which construction or renewal of a sidewalk within
the City is proposed, said owners shall have the right to finance their portion
of the cost of said construction or renewal of said sidewalk in question with
the City of Aledo upon the following terms and conditions. First, said owner or
owners must sign a promissory note payable to the City of Aledo, Illinois,
promising to pay said owner's or owners' portion of the sidewalks cost in
question in five (5) equal annual installment payments plus accrued interest at
the rate of six percent (6%) per annum due on the outstanding balance that may
exist from time to time under the terms of said promissory note, the first said
equal principal payment plus accrued interest at the rate of six percent (6%)
per annum to be paid on or before the first day of the thirteenth month
following the month during which construction or renewal of said sidewalk or
sidewalks in question has been completed. Thereafter, each equal annual
installment payment plus accrued interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per
annum on the outstanding balance shall be paid on or before the first day of
each consecutive month immediately after a respective twelve (12) month period
has run from said beginning date as herein described.
Second, said owner or owners shall execute a promissory note that provides that
in the event of default and if such default is not made good within thirty (30)
days, the entire principal sum and accrued interest shall at once become due
and payable without notice by the city of Aledo.
Third, this promissory note shall further provide that in the event it becomes
necessary to collect said note through an attorney, said owner or owners will
agree to pay all costs of collection, including a reasonable attorney fee and
all court costs.
Last of all, the owner or owners desiring to avail themselves of the benefits
of this financing section pertaining to sidewalks shall further agree that said
amount due shall be a lien against the property and said owner or owners shall
be obligated to sign any and all necessary documents that may be required in
order to place the amount financed for construction or renewal of any sidewalk
or sidewalks pursuant to the provisions of this section as a lien against the
real estate in question upon which said sidewalk or sidewalks have been
constructed. (Ord. 2/78, 6-19-1978)
CHAPTER 6
WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS
SECTION:
8-6-1:   Water And Sewer Systems Combined
8-6-2:   Prohibited Uses Of Water System
8-6-3:   Rules And Regulations
8-6-3-1:   Water Lines, Owner's Responsibility
8-6-3-2:   Sewer Laterals, Owner's Responsibility
8-6-4:   Agree To Assessment
8-6-5:   Monies Collected, Credited To Fund
8-6-6:   Climbing On Water System Towers
8-6-7:   Meters
8-6-8:   Water And Sewer Rates
8-6-9:   Storm Sewer Drains
8-6-10:   Cross Connection Control And Backflow Prevention
8-6-10-1:   Definitions
8-6-10-2:   Scope
8-6-10-3:   Purpose
8-6-10-4:   Water System
8-6-10-5:   Violations, Penalties And Liabilities
8-6-10-6:   Administration And Enforcement
8-6-10-7:   City's Right Of Entry

8-6-10-9:   Surveys; Investigations

8-6-1: WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS COMBINED:
The existing municipally owned waterworks system and the existing sanitary
sewerage system shall be combined, maintained and operated together as a
combined waterworks and sewerage system and said combined system shall include
the entire waterworks and sewerage systems of the city, including all the
improvements and extensions thereto. The combined municipal waterworks and
sewerage system of said city shall be operated on a fiscal year basis which
shall conform to the city's fiscal year, and the entire revenues derived from
the operation of said combined system shall be set aside as collected and be
deposited in a separate fund to be designated as the "waterworks and sewerage
fund" of the city which shall be used only in paying the cost of operation and
maintenance of said system, providing an adequate depreciation fund and paying
the principal of and interest on any waterworks and sewerage revenue bonds of
the city that are payable by their terms only from such revenues, which may
hereafter be issued. (Ord. 3/38, 9-12-1938)
8-6-2: PROHIBITED USES OF WATER SYSTEM:
   (A)   No person shall interfere in any manner with any public or private
hydrant or stopcock, or deposit any dirt or other material in any stopcock box,
or turn any public or private stopcock, or do any act tending to obstruct the
use thereof, or injure in any manner any building, machinery, pipe, apparatus,
fixtures or tools of or belonging to, the system of waterworks of the city
without permission from the general superintendent or his duly authorized agent
or representative.
   (B)   No person shall make any excavation in any street for the purpose of
laying water pipes of any description nor tap any water pipe or main, or any
service pipe after being laid down, without written permission from the general
superintendent or his duly authorized agent or representative, and then only
such persons as are duly authorized to perform such work, and the particular
persons so to be employed shall in such case be named in the permit.
   (C)   No plumber or other person shall make any addition, or alteration to
any water main, pipe or water fixture connected with the waterworks,
distributing pipe to conduct water into adjoining premises or into stables,
baths, water closets, wash basins, cisterns, fountains, or for any other
purpose whatever, without application having first been made to, and written
permission obtained from the general superintendent or his duly authorized
agent or representative.
   (D)   No person shall make any excavation in any street or highway within
four and one-half feet (41/2') of any laid water pipe or main while the ground
is frozen, except by permission of the general superintendent or his duly
authorized agent or representative. (Ord. 8/1889, 10-23-1889; amd. Ord. 8/1904,
1-16-1905)
8-6-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   (A)   The Mayor and Council shall appoint all necessary officers and agents
for furnishing water, collecting water rents, and fix the term of office,
salaries of such officers and agents.
   (B)   All work done in the streets must be done under the supervision of,
and subject to the direction and approval of the General Superintendent or his
duly authorized agent or representative.
   (C)   Each ferrule inserted in the mains or distributing pipes, and the
service pipe to be laid shall be of the size specified in the permit and order;
and the person to whom such work is entrusted shall report to the General
Superintendent or his duly authorized agent or representative regularly and
truly the exact location, number and sizes of all taps inserted and the length
of service pipe laid in each case. (Ord. 8/1889, 10-23-1889; amd. Ord. 8/1904,
1-16-1905)
   (D)   Applications for permits to connect service pipe with main or supply
pipe shall be made to the City Clerk and there shall be payable to the City of
Aledo at the time of making the application a fee pursuant to title 13,
"Schedule Of Fees", of this Code. However, any fees or costs above and beyond
the normal fees for a residential customer shall be charged for the cost to the
City for the installation, fixtures and meter set in the amount that it exceeds
a normal residential installation cost. (Ord. 16/2017, 6-5-2017)
   (E)   In making excavations in streets or highways for the laying of service
pipes, the planks, bricks or paving stones, and earth removed shall be
deposited in a manner that will occasion the least inconvenience to the public
and provide for the passage of water along the gutters. Suitable barricades
must be erected around the excavations and amber lights maintained at night if
unfilled before nightfall. (Ord. 8/1889, 10-23-1889; amd. Ord. 8/1904, 1-16-
1905; Ord. 15/92, 2-1-1993)
   (F)   All taps must be forty five degrees (45°) from the top of the main or
pipe, and in no case within fifteen inches (15") of the bell or hub. (Ord. 15/
92, 2-1-1993)
   (G)   Before filling the trench, the service cock in the street mains must
be covered with a suitable cover and the earth must be well rammed under the
main and to a level with the top thereof; from thence the trench must be filled
in layers of not more than twelve inches (12") in depth, and each layer
thoroughly rammed or puddled to prevent settling.
   (H)   It shall be the duty of the General Superintendent or his duly
authorized agent or representative to supervise and direct these operations
and, from time to time, report to the Council the manner in which the plumber
performs his work and the condition in which he finds the filling, relaying and
paving has been done.
   (I)   No water taken from the waterworks of the City shall permit the
service pipe or fixtures connected therewith to become out of good repair, or
unprotected from injury by frost.
   (J)   Hydrants, taps, hose, water closets, urinals, baths and other fixtures
will not be permitted to be kept running when not in actual use.
   (K)   All service pipes shall be laid to a depth that will leave at least
five feet (5') of earth over the top of the pipe at every point. (Ord. 8/1889,
10-23-1889; amd. Ord. 8/1904, 1-16-1905)
   (L)   All pipes used as service pipes shall be of ductile iron, copper, ABS
plastic, PB and PE plastic or PVC and shall be submitted to and stand a
hydraulic pressure of one hundred sixty (160) pounds to the square inch. All
nonconductive buried service lines shall be installed with copper "tracing"
wire.
   (M)   Indoor plumbing shall be constructed of pipe in weight at least equal
to the kind of pipe known as "extra strength" and shall be submitted to and
stand a hydraulic pressure of one hundred sixty (160) pounds to the square
inch. The composition of indoor plumbing pipe shall be restricted to those
types named in subsection (L) of this section. (Ord. 15/92, 2-1-1993)
   (N)   No private hydrant shall be located on the sidewalk or elsewhere
beyond the limits of the lot or grounds owned by the party or parties to whom
the permit is issued, except by permission of the Superintendent of the Water
Department. (Ord. 8/1889, 10-23-1889)
   (O)   Each separate building or premises connecting to the City water
distribution system shall have a separate and independent service line
connecting directly to the City main. Each service line shall be equipped with
a curb stop installed on the service line at the property line of the premises
to be served. (Ord. 15/92, 2-1-1993)
   (P)   When it shall be necessary to break up a sidewalk for the putting in
of water service pipes, there shall be maintained a safe crossing for foot
passengers, and if found necessary to remove the whole width of the walk,
travel may be shut off for the time being by the erection of suitable barriers.
(Ord. 8/1889, 10-23-1889)
   (Q)   All applications for water service shall state fully and truly the
purposes for which it is required; and when paying the water rents, the parties
shall be required to truly answer all proper questions relative to consumption
